Thus, when wind prevails, movement arises. Wind’s harm to humans is swift and ever-changing: when the interstices open, cold chills arise; when cold closes, heat and oppression follow. Wind injury in spring’s *jia-yi* days is called Liver wind. Liver wind’s signs include profuse sweating, aversion to wind, melancholy, a slightly greenish complexion, dry throat, frequent anger, and occasional hatred of women. Diagnosis lies beneath the eyes, where the color is green.

**Discourse on Liver Disease and Sinew Spasms:**
Liver disease with sinew spasms occurs because the Liver unites with the sinews. When the Foot *Jueyin* Channel is insufficient, the vessels fail to nourish. Without nourishment, wind evil easily invades, contending with the sinews and vessels, causing spasms and contractions. Moreover, the Liver stores wind toxin, and *qi* pours into the arms, head, neck, shoulders, back, waist, and feet, causing sinew spasms, cramping, piercing pain, or swollen limbs, dizziness, black spots obscuring vision, vomiting, hiccups, and reduced appetite. Generally, facial swelling is called wind—wind is yang *qi*. Thus, all wind tremors and dizziness belong to the Liver, and all sudden rigidity belongs to wind.

**Wind Strike:**
Wind strike occurs when wind *qi* invades a person. Wind is the *qi* of the four seasons, distributed across the eight directions, governing the growth and nourishment of all things. Wind coming from its native direction causes few deaths or illnesses. Wind from non-native directions causes many deaths and illnesses. When it causes disease, it lurks between the skin and flesh, internally unable to penetrate and externally unable to disperse. When it enters the channels and vessels, moving through the five *zang*, it generates disease in each *zang* and *fu* accordingly. In Liver wind strike, one can only squat and cannot lower the head. If greenish color encircles both eyes and extends to the forehead, with greenish lips and a yellowish face, it is treatable. There is also *xi* wind and fan wind, which strike people subtly.

Severe wind escalates into *li* wind, where wind-cold lingers in the vessels without departing—this is called *li* wind. It may also be named cold-heat. Thus, all winds归属于liver wind, the origin of the hundred diseases. Like bandit winds that strike repeatedly, or vacuous evils that assail morning and night, one must avoid them as one would avoid arrows and stones. When the liver is replete, drain it with sour; employ *xu* qi to [treat] its vacuity, and supplement it with acrid. Avoid drafts—this is the model of nurturing life.

As the seasonal nodes shift, the months of *hai*, *zi*, and *chou* remain winter, when winter *qi* moves south. In the tenth month, human *qi* resides on the left with the heart; in the eleventh and twelfth months, it also lies on the left with the kidneys. Winter *qi* begins at the *biao* (exterior), which is both the head and the tail. Some say it begins at the front, with winter *qi* in the bone marrow, its *shu* points at the waist and thighs—the waist being the palace of the kidneys. Winter *qi* resides in the kidneys and also in the yin, affecting the four limbs. In winter, one is prone to *bi* impediment and reversal, while yang diseases arise in winter.

In the eleventh month, human *qi* lies on the left with the kidneys. Moreover, winter rules the kidneys, corresponding to *ren* and *gui*. *Ren* governs the left hand’s Greater Yin, while *gui* governs the right hand’s Lesser Yin. Winter takes stomach *qi* as its root, so in winter, one nurtures yin and should eat warming foods. To treat the kidneys with heat yet counter with cold at this time—there are methods for harmonizing the spirit: rise late and retire early, awaiting sunlight, avoiding cold and seeking warmth, and not allowing sweat to leak from the skin. This is winter’s response to the Dao of storing and nurturing.

If one does not distance oneself from cold, cold will arrive; when cold arrives, hardness and blockage ensue, giving rise to abdominal fullness, pain, urgency, and diarrhea. Its pulse is like stone. To act contrary is to invite illness. Thus, heaven employs cold, and one may distance oneself from cold. Following this preserves life; opposing it harms the kidneys. The kidneys loathe dryness and also fear dampness—dampness being the *qi* of earth.

If one is harmed by cold in winter, one will surely contract warm disease in spring. Among the hundred diseases of humanity, none is greater than harm from cold. Its patterns: on the first day, Greater Yang receives it; on the second, Yang Brightness receives it; on the third, Lesser Yang receives it; on the fourth, Greater Yin receives it; on the fifth, Lesser Yin receives it; on the sixth, Reverting Yin receives it. By the seventh day, Greater Yang’s disease wanes; by the eighth, Yang Brightness’ disease wanes; by the ninth, Lesser Yang’s disease wanes; by the tenth, Greater Yin’s disease wanes; by the eleventh, Lesser Yin’s disease wanes; by the twelfth, Reverting Yin’s disease wanes. This is the waxing and waning transmission among the twelve channels. If contrary, three cycles will pass before it ceases. These three cycles refer to the three yin and three yang channels of the hands and feet.

Only the perfected of antiquity did not contract warm disease in spring, for they stored essence in the kidneys. Essence is the root of the body. The *Classic* states: "Essence, blood, nature, and life are one with the Dao." Thus, the sage treasures essence, for essence is most true. From ancient times to the present, those called "true persons" excel at being unborn and untransformed, merging with the Dao as one. This is what is meant by "not being transformed into a human." They can transform others, but if one nurtures life and honors existence, not contracting warm disease is profound—this is called "wondrous truth."

As the shadow shifts and the Dipper moves, the proper alignment of the mid-winter month is *zi*, where the *Fu* hexagram’s first nine yang line is born, revealing the heart of heaven and earth. This remains winter, and at this juncture, in the north of *Kan*, the Dark Heavenly Thearch manifests boundless transformations, presiding over the karmic retribution of good and evil in the human realm, its influence clear as echo and shadow. The pitch corresponds to Yellow Bell.

The Dao of heaven binds the southeast; its image above is the Precious Cauldron Palace, and below, the state of *Qi*. Its *qi* resides in the human kidneys. The kidneys are the *zang*, the bladder the *fu*; their phase is water, their nature severe, their *qi* cold. Bitter cold harms the form. Their note is *yu*, they rule in winter, are cut off in the *ji* season, and die on *wu* and *ji* days.

The kidneys are the official of strength and skill, from which ingenuity arises. They are the dwelling of essence. Their luster is in the hair, their filling in the bone marrow. The kidneys have two lobes: the left is the kidney that stores will, where joyful will and spirit guard within; the right is the life-gate that stores essence. The kidneys are yin *qi*, the root of the five *zang*, governing the body’s bones, marrow, and teeth. Teeth are the root of bones, also called the surplus of bone. Yet standing too long harms the bones, straining the kidneys.

When the kidneys are taxed, the back is difficult to bend or raise, urination is unsmooth, the color is reddish-yellow with lingering dribbling, the penis aches internally, the genitals are damp, sores appear on the scrotum, and the lower abdomen is full and tense. It is also said: exerting strength to lift heavy objects or sitting too long on damp ground harms the kidneys. When the kidneys are harmed, essence is scant, the waist and back ache, and reversal cold ensues.

The kidneys open at the ears and the anterior and posterior yin. Their condition is observed at the ears. Their color is black, their fluid is saliva, their odor is putrid, their flavor is salty. Salty first enters the kidneys; the kidneys desire salty, but salty courses through the blood. In blood disease, do not eat much salt. Eating too much salt causes the vessels to congeal, the complexion to darken, and the flesh to contract, while heart *qi* rebels and great bone *qi* is affected.

Taxing the kidneys values nurturing the bones, so kidney yin disease arises in the bones. If one cannot stand or walk for long, the bones will tremble and weaken. If one then overexerts, kidney *qi* is harmed, and the high bones are damaged. Those who attain strength live; those who lose it die. The kidneys desire firmness, so eat bitter to firm them. Bitter supplements, salty drains. The kidneys suffer from dryness and urgency, so eat acrid to moisten them. The kidneys loathe dryness and also fear dampness—dampness being the *qi* of earth.

When essence and *qi* converge in the kidneys, fear arises. The kidneys generate fear, and fear harms them. The kidneys forbid scorched, scalding hot food, warm grilled clothing, or heated garments. If there is illness, ask what flavors the patient desires to know the disease’s origin. In kidney disease, observe the complexion externally.

Greenish-black indicates pain; white indicates cold.
When the kidneys are hot, the cheeks flush red—the area below the mouth is the cheek.
In kidney heat, the complexion is black and the teeth wither; one speaks of "withered teeth."
When kidney *qi* is affected by wind, the muscles darken, extending to the skin.
Kidney *qi* connects to the ears; when the kidneys are harmonious, the ears can hear the five sounds.
In kidney disease, the voice changes, manifesting as yawning (yin) or sneezing (yang), groaning, shivering, and trembling.

Each of the five viscera has its own essence, which flows and pours into the kidneys.
The kidneys serve as the capital and the gatekeeper’s post.
The foot *Shaoyin* kidney channel: its *jing-well* (wood) point is *Yongquan* (Bubbling Spring), two points located in the depression at the center of the sole, found by curling the toes.
Its *ying-spring* (fire) point is *Rangu* (Blazing Valley), two points in the depression anterior to the ankle, below the prominent bone.
Its *shu-stream* (earth) point is *Taixi* (Great Ravine), two points posterior to the medial malleolus, in the depression above the heel bone.
If the pulse is cut off, death follows; it is incurable.
Another *shu* point lies below the fourteenth vertebra, on either side.

The kidney’s *yuan-source* emerges at *Daxi* (Great Ravine); its *jing-river* (metal) point is *Fuliu* (Returning Current), two points two *cun* above the medial malleolus.
At *geng* hours during the day, the human *qi* resides in the foot *Shaoyin* kidney channel.
By *you* hours, the human *qi* also dwells in the kidney’s network vessels.
*Gui* governs the left hand’s *Shaoyin*, and its *qi* also governs kidney visceral diseases.
*Zi* corresponds to the eleventh month of the year, governing the left foot’s *Taiyin*, and the human *qi* resides in the left side and in the kidneys.

Its *he-sea* (water) point is *Yingu* (Yin Valley), two points posterior to the medial condyle of the tibia, between the large tendon below and the small tendon above.
The foot *Shaoyin* channel courses through the chest as the *Shaoyin* winter pulse.
It begins beneath the little toe, slanting toward the sole, emerging below the *Rangu* bone, following the posterior aspect of the medial malleolus, branching into the heel, ascending along the inner calf, emerging at the medial side of the popliteal fossa, then traveling up the posterior thigh, penetrating the spine, connecting to the kidneys and linking with the bladder.

The balanced kidney pulse is deep, hidden, and moderate. In people, the pulse is often insufficient.
If form and *qi* are unharmed but the pulse is excessive, death follows.
If form and *qi* are insufficient but the pulse is unharmed and excessive, life continues.
The pulse governs life and death—how vast its significance!

The twenty-four types of pulses serve as the essential framework:
The *floating pulse* is yang. It indicates heat, pain, vomiting, distension, obstruction, panting, reversal, internal binding, fullness, and inability to eat.
The appearance of the floating pulse resembles duckweed on water or floating clouds in the wind.

The *hollow pulse* vanishes upon pressure but returns when lifted.
Thus, dribbling, roughness, and pain arise from blood loss.

The *surging pulse* indicates distension, fullness, pain, heat, and vexation.
It resembles water flowing together, waves surging and rising.

The *slippery pulse* indicates vomiting, fullness, cough, heat, hidden phlegm, retained food, blood stasis, menstrual blockage, possession, and *qi* and blood excess.
Since all are replete, it slides like pearls.

The *rapid pulse* indicates heat, deficiency, vomiting, pain, vexation, thirst, and fullness.

The *skipping pulse* relates to *qi*, blood, fluids, food, and phlegm.
Thus, yang excess causes skipping, while yin excess causes binding.

The *wiry pulse* indicates cold, pain, fluids, malaria, water *qi*, central deficiency, reversal cold, cramping, and cold accumulations.
When lifted, it feels taut like a drawn bowstring.

The *tight pulse* indicates cold, pain in the head, bones, and flesh, cough, and panting.
All tight pulses signify cold, resembling a twisted rope.

The *deep pulse* indicates repletion, water, cold, panting, concretions, and conglomerations.

The *hidden pulse* indicates cholera, mounting conglomerations, water *qi*, sloppy diarrhea, retained phlegm and food, *qi* surging upward, and foul pus penetrating the flesh.

The *soft pulse* indicates deficiency, impediment, spontaneous sweating, *qi* weakness, heaviness below, softness and weakness, internal heat with external cold, incontinence, and difficult urination.

The *leathery pulse* indicates fullness, urgency, and the struggle between deficiency cold and change.
It signifies departure from the old, a fixed and unyielding state.

The *replete pulse*: when pathogenic *qi* is abundant, it is replete; when essence is depleted, it is deficient.

The *faint pulse* indicates deficiency, weakness, nosebleed, vomiting, diarrhea, sweating, cramping, central cold, faint weakness, and *qi* deficiency.

The *rough pulse* is yin. It indicates blood deficiency, sweating, *qi* insufficiency, reversal cold, dysentery, and heart pain.
If one does not drink, fluids are insufficient, the pulse pathways are obstructed, and the body becomes rough.

The *fine pulse* is extremely thin and soft—called *faint*—yet sharper than faint.
When it is merely fine, it is termed *fine*.
It signifies true *qi* deficiency, aching shins, cold marrow, lack of strength, and essence depletion.

The *soggy pulse* is extremely soft, floating, fine, and soggy.
It resembles silk cloth in water, perceptible with a light touch.
Due to blood deficiency, it cannot fill and solidify.

The *weak pulse* is weak and deficient.
It indicates wind-heat and spontaneous sweating.
Since weakness governs yin, deficiency, and palpitations, it is so.

The *deficient pulse* indicates cold, deficiency, timidity, weakness, undigested food, and summerheat injury.
If innate essence is not secure, defense and nourishment lose their guard, *qi* and blood decline and deplete—how can the pulse not be soft, weak, and deficient?

The *scattered pulse*: when the six *fu* organs’ *qi* is cut off externally, the hands and feet grow cold, and *qi* surges upward to the five viscera.
When cut off internally, there is uncontrolled diarrhea, and in severe cases, numbness.
All such pulses scatter; scattering means failure to gather—dangerous indeed.

The *moderate pulse*: below, it indicates wind, cold, weakness, impediment, pain, numbness, *qi* insufficiency, and dizziness.

The *slow pulse* indicates cold and pain. All yin conditions pertain to cold; when cold prevails, the pulse floats, water stagnates, and edema swells.

The *bound pulse* indicates phlegm, rheum, blood, and *qi*. Within the span of one day and night—13,500 breaths—a pulse that halts and then resumes may be called *bound*. It is also described as moving to and fro, gathering and then retreating, hence *bound*. When the four limbs grow sluggish and pain strikes intermittently, this is the affliction of the *bound pulse*.

The *intermittent pulse* arises when one organ fails and another takes its place. Its manifestations include emaciation, an inability to speak—clear signs of exhausted innate essence.

The *stirring pulse* indicates pain, fright, spasms, diarrhea, and terror. When yang seeks to descend but yin resists, or yin seeks to ascend but yang resists, the two forces contend, unable to move up or down. The pulse surges and strikes, rising abruptly—thus the form of the *stirring pulse* appears. Where yang stirs, yang is deficient; where yin stirs, yin is deficient.

The classics state: *The pulse determines life and death, governs all diseases, and regulates deficiency and excess—one cannot be ignorant of it.* To treat excess as excess and deficiency as deficiency is to harm the insufficient and augment the abundant—such a course leads clearly to death.

Now, the etymology of *pulse*: the human pulse corresponds to the moon, governed by the single trigram *Kan*. As water and moon, it is marked by a dot—representing the high waters of the upper pool. The middle is the central pool, its waters deep and still. The lower is the surging pulse of the multitude. When the *ying* streams feed the great ravines, the three waters flow and irrigate, granting enduring longevity. This inexhaustible fluid nearly approaches the Dao.

The ancients taught: *The kidney’s meridians belong to water—this single drop from the upper pool has sustained me to this day.* The art of nurturing life lies in regulating *qi*. The kidney stores the *qi* of bone marrow; kidney *qi* is cold and biting. Cold is yin *qi*. When cold evil invades the kidney, it causes bone pain and yin impediment. Yin impediment resists palpation, brings abdominal distension, lumbar pain, difficult defecation, and intermittent dizziness with pain in the shoulders, back, neck, and nape.

Kidney disease manifests as swollen cheeks and throat, panting, coughing, heaviness of the body, night sweats, and aversion to wind. The kidney’s afflictions reach the small junctions of flesh and sinew, even to the bone marrow.

The kidney’s correspondences: it resembles water, rules in winter, and its pulse is stone-like and deep. Its orifice is the ear, its sound is groaning, its odor is putrid, its flavor is salty, its fluid is spittle, it nourishes the bones, its color is black, and its spirit is the will. It belongs to the Foot Lesser Yin meridian and pairs with the bladder. The bladder is the *fu* organ, governing the exterior; the kidney is the *zang* organ, governing the interior. When kidney *qi* flourishes, it becomes the will. In excess, it causes abdominal distension, undigested diarrhea, bodily swelling, panting, coughing, sweating, aversion to wind, dark complexion, and yellow urine—this is kidney *qi* in excess, and purging is required. When kidney *qi* is insufficient, it causes reversal cold in the limbs, lumbar and dorsal chill, chest pain, tinnitus or deafness—this is kidney *qi* in deficiency, and supplementation is required.

A comprehensive discussion of the kidney: the Foot Lesser Yin meridian of the kidney and the Foot Greater Yang meridian of the bladder stand as exterior and interior. They rule in winter, resemble water, and their pulse is deep. They nourish the bone marrow, their spirit is essence and will, their orifice is the ear, their sound is groaning, their odor is putrid, their flavor is salty, their fluid is spittle, their color is black, and their *qi* is closed and stored. Thus, one should retire early and rise late, awaiting daylight, avoiding cold and seeking warmth, disturbing nothing. This is the Dao of nurturing the *zang* in accordance with yang. To oppose winter’s *qi* is to diminish yin’s storage, leaving kidney *qi* alone and sunken.

Its symptoms include lower abdominal distension and fullness, yellow-red urine with lingering dribbling, frequent and painful urination—this is kidney excess. In kidney heat disease, lumbar pain arises first, followed by aching shins, bitter thirst, frequent drinking, and fever. Generally, winter brings cold damage, spring brings warm epidemics, and summer brings heat disease. When heat contends, the nape grows painful and stiff, the shins cold and aching, the feet hot, and speech is unwelcome. If the condition reverses, the nape pain becomes dull and indistinct.

When kidney heat is in excess, it generates wind, darkening the skin and flesh. If in winter, *ren* and *gui* days, evil invades, it becomes kidney wind. The symptoms of kidney wind include profuse sweating, aversion to wind, facial swelling, spinal pain preventing upright posture, a sooty complexion, and difficulty with private matters. Diagnosis lies in the skin’s black hue—thus the kidney resembles water. Its *qi* is cold and biting, for cold is yin *qi*.

When kidney evil enters the liver, tears turn cold; in excess, they congeal into weeping, accompanied by sinew spasms and tension, as well as bone pain. When the kidney transmits cold to the liver, it causes abscesses and shortness of breath. The liver stores blood; when cold enters, yang *qi* fails to disperse, so blood congeals and *qi* stagnates. When evil resides in the kidney, it causes bone pain and yin impediment. Yin impediment resists palpation, brings abdominal distension, lumbar pain, difficult defecation, and intermittent dizziness with pain in the shoulders, back, neck, and nape.

Generally, when wind, cold, and damp *qi* converge, they cause impediment. When cold prevails, the pulse floats, water stagnates, and edema swells. When kidney will and *qi* are insufficient, reversal *qi* surges upward. If kidney *qi* is assailed by evil, water cannot moisten downward, leading to desiccation and dryness—hence difficult defecation. All cold causes contraction and withdrawal, all belonging to the kidney. All reversal, constipation, and leakage belong to the lower body. All diseases where fluids are clear and cold belong to cold.

In treatment, avoid cold in cold seasons; if violated, cold arrives. When cold arrives, it hardens, causing abdominal fullness and pain, and urgent diarrhea arises. Thus, cold harms the form. If blockage and obstruction occur, with lumbar and dorsal stiffness, reduced appetite, and fatigue, this is kidney deficiency.

If a person suffers two internal insufficiencies—first, *long* disease with tens of urinations a day; second, the Greater Yin pulse faint and fine as a hair—then their death is clearly imminent.

For those with severe essence insufficiency, replenish with rich flavors. For those with physical insufficiency, warm with qi. Combining qi and flavor in ingestion can replenish essence and augment qi. For kidney deficiency, use bitter to tonify. For excess, use salty to purge. Thus, the methods for regulating qi involve blowing treatments, with restoration and peace as the aim—this is the general outline of the art.

As the year wanes and transforms, the cold stars conclude in the final month of winter, when the *chou* earthly branch governs the *Lin* hexagram, and the pitch aligns with *Great Regulator*. The celestial Dao moves westward; its image above is the *Grinding Palace*, below is *Wu*, and its qi resides in the human spleen. The spleen is the *zang*-organ, the stomach its *fu*-organ, both symbolizing earth. It flourishes in the late seasons, wanes in spring, and perishes in *jia-yi* days. Its note is *gong*, its color yellow, its nature both tranquil and harmonious. It nourishes the flesh, manifests in the lips, savors sweetness, emits fragrance, produces saliva, and expresses itself in song.

The spleen stores intention and generates thought; excessive thought harms the spleen. The spleen is the official of the granary and the root of the body’s encampment. When spleen qi converges, the five flavors emerge. Its bloom and glory appear in the four whites of the lips, and its fullness resides in the muscles. As human flesh corresponds to earth, prolonged sitting injures it, for the flesh labors on behalf of the spleen. When the spleen labors, the root of the tongue becomes stiff and bitter, making it difficult to swallow saliva.

It is also said that excessive fullness injures the spleen. When the spleen is injured, one tends to belch, desires to lie down, appears yellow in the face, and speaks with effort. Fatigue from food and exertion harms the spleen, which opens at the mouth; when the spleen is harmonious, one discerns the five grains. The spleen is the utmost yin within yin, its earthly position in the southwest, flourishing in the fourth month of each season—yet in winter, one should not lift the heels, as in the months of *chen*, *wei*, and *xu*.

Those who cultivate life must attend particularly to the spleen. Craving sweetness, sweetness first enters the spleen and flesh. For those with flesh ailments, avoid excessive sweetness, for it causes bone pain and hair loss. The spleen desires moderation; consume sweetness to relax it. The spleen suffers from dampness; urgently consume bitter to dry it. The spleen forbids warm clothing, overfullness, damp ground, and wet garments. It detests dampness and fears wind, for wind is the command of wood.

When essence and qi converge in the spleen, those who fear spleen heat exhibit yellow complexion and twitching flesh, with the nose reddening first. The nose occupies the center of the face, where earth flourishes. Its changes and movements manifest in song, joy, retching, belching, and swallowing sounds.

The Foot Greater Yin Spleen Channel begins at *Hidden White*, two points on the inner tip of the big toe, a leek-leaf’s width from the nail. Its fire spring is *Great Metropolis*, two points in the depression behind the big toe’s base joint. Its earth transport is *Great White*, two points in the depression below the inner ankle’s prominence. The spleen’s transport point lies below the eleventh vertebra on either side. Its source emerges at *Great White*. Its metal channel is *Shang Mound*, two points in the depression slightly anterior to the inner ankle. At *xun* (9–11 a.m.), human qi resides in the Foot Greater Yin Spleen Channel. By *si* (9–11 a.m.), qi also flows through the spleen’s network vessels. *Si* governs the Lesser Yang of the right hand, and its qi also governs spleen organ diseases. *Chou* (1–3 a.m.), the twelfth month, governs the Lesser Yin of the left foot, where human qi also resides in the left and in the kidneys.

Its water convergence is *Yin Mound Spring*, two points below the knee on the inner side of the lower leg, beneath the auxiliary bone. The Foot Greater Yin Spleen Channel arises at the big toe’s tip, follows the inner white flesh of the toe, passes behind the ankle bone, ascends the anterior edge of the inner ankle, then the inner shin, crossing in front of the Jueyin to ascend the inner anterior thigh into the abdomen, where it connects to the spleen and networks the stomach. It ascends the diaphragm, flanks the throat, connects to the root of the tongue, and disperses beneath it.

Thus, the spleen’s balanced pulse is moderate; its perverse pulse is wiry. When the pulse deviates from constancy, qi follows. The spleen stores the qi of muscles and flesh. When spleen qi converges, if evil resides in the spleen, the stomach falls ill, and the muscles ache. The spleen’s disease affects the root of the tongue; thus, its transport point lies in the spine’s center.

Spleen disease manifests as heaviness in the body, flaccid muscles, weak feet that cannot be lifted, and a tendency to cramp, with pain under the soles. The spleen’s correspondences: it symbolizes earth, flourishes in late summer, its pulse is moderate, its orifice the mouth, its sound song, its odor fragrance, its flavor sweetness, its fluid saliva, its nourishment the flesh, its color yellow, and it stores intention. The Foot Greater Yin is its channel, paired with the stomach, which is the *fu*-organ governing the exterior. The spleen is the *zang*-organ governing containment.

When spleen qi is exuberant, it shapes the form; in excess, it causes illness: abdominal distension and fullness, inhibited urination, heaviness in the body, constant hunger, weak feet that cannot be lifted, a tendency to cramp, and pain under the soles—this is spleen qi excess, and purging is appropriate. When spleen qi is insufficient, the four limbs fail to function, with undigested food in diarrhea, vomiting, counterflow, abdominal distension, and borborygmi—this is spleen qi deficiency, and tonifying is appropriate.

In summary, the spleen resides in the center, flourishing in mid-summer and the fourth month of each season. Its pulse arrives large and moderate—this is the spleen’s balanced pulse. If it is deep, fine, and weak, the spleen is deficient. Deficiency causes abdominal fullness, undigested food, vomiting, diarrhea, inability to use the four limbs, shortness of breath, aversion to human voices, and dreams of insufficient food—all signs of spleen deficiency.

When the yin pulse at the right *guan* position is tight and replete, the spleen is in excess. Excess manifests as heaviness in the body, inability to turn, heat and oppression in the chest, dry and scorched lips, cheek pain, heart vexation, throat discomfort, sores at the root of the tongue, deep and heavy speech, dreams of singing and music, and lassitude in the four limbs—these are signs of spleen excess.

In spleen heat disease, the head first feels heavy, the cheeks ache, the heart is vexed, the complexion turns green, and one desires to vomit with fever. Excessive heat relaxes the sinews, dissolves the bones, and melts the flesh. When heat contends fiercely, lumbar pain arises, making bending and lifting impossible, with abdominal fullness, diarrhea, pain in both cheeks, and counterflow—death occurs on *jia-yi* days.

The spleen governs the form. When form is in excess, there is abdominal distension with inhibited urination and defecation. The spleen abhors dampness; when dampness prevails, there is watery diarrhea, and in severe cases, water retention with edema and swelling. All swelling and fullness due to dampness pertain to the spleen. When the spleen is in excess, it generates wind. In late summer, injury by evil on *wu-ji* days gives rise to spleen wind. The signs of spleen wind include profuse sweating with aversion to wind, lassitude in the body, reluctance to move the four limbs, a pale and slightly yellow complexion, and loss of appetite. In diagnosis, observe the nose—its color is yellow, hence spleen wind manifests as a yellow nose. The nose occupies the center of the face, resembling the *kun* trigram’s yielding nature. The central region’s people eat a varied diet and do not labor, thus their illnesses often involve atrophy. They suffer from alternating chills and fever, and the appropriate treatment is daoyin, anmo, and daoyao exercises.

The above describes spleen diseases of excess, which should be drained with bitter flavors. The precise method lies in the regulation of qi: exhalation facilitates its flow. Inhalation follows yin inward, while exhalation follows yang outward. For spleen deficiency, it should be supplemented with sweet flavors. Additionally, one may raise the shoulders, retract the neck, and apply pressure with the feet. Here ends the *Yuan Yuan Dao Miao Dong Zhen Ji Pian*. Below follows *Yuan Yuan Dao Miao Dong Zhen Ji Pian Xia*.

Master Li Jingyuan of the True Origin Gate offers this commentary:

The physician Lu exhaustively examined the five viscera, noting that within the human throat lie three passages: one for food, one for qi, and one for water, each sequentially propelling the others. The passages for food and water share a single orifice, converging together into the stomach. The upper orifice leads to the lungs, connecting to the Greater Yin meridian, descending through the abdomen, reaching the spine’s center, then circling beneath the navel to join the Conception, Thoroughfare, and Governing Vessels at the Cinnabar Field—the sea of generative qi. Three inches below the navel, spanning four inches in width, it adheres between the spine and the two kidneys. Known also as the Great Sea, within its waters dwells a spirit-turtle that draws in primordial qi, circulating it upward past the navel, weaving through the stomach, penetrating the liver and diaphragm, and entering the lungs. Here, the ascending and descending qi facilitate the ebb and flow of breath, for this is the sole passage above the lungs. The passages for water and food both enter the stomach, entirely dependent on the qi of the Cinnabar Field to transform and transmute their essence. Water and grain separate into the pure and turbid, traversing the small and large intestines, where the interplay of yin and yang qi governs their transformation and transmission. When yang qi prevails, water and grain are refined; when yin qi dominates, the dregs remain unrefined, giving rise to cold and pain. This occurs when yang is obstructed by yin and fails to descend, or when yin, lacking yang, fails to ascend—such is the principle of yin and yang’s ascent and descent.

Below the throat, the two lobes of the lungs appear, serving as the Florid Canopy that shelters all the viscera. Beneath the lungs lies the heart, enveloped in a yellow fatty membrane of a reddish-yellow hue. The heart’s form is pointed, elongated, round, and flat, its color a blend of black, red, green, and yellow, with pores distinct and unalike. Below the heart lies the diaphragm, and beneath that, the stomach, coiled to hold several *sheng* of matter, encased in a yellow fatty membrane resembling a banner’s flame. To the left lies the liver with its two lobes, the shorter of which bears the gallbladder. Beside the stomach on the left rests the spleen, sharing its membrane, resembling horse liver in its reddish-purple hue. Below lies the small intestine, coiled in fifteen loops, gleaming and pure, transmuting and conveying matter. To the right lies the large intestine, coiled in sixteen loops, containing dregs and enveloped in yellow fat, clumped together. Below resides the bladder, also gleaming and pure, lacking any external orifice, entirely reliant on the process of transformation—whereby fluids enter as urine.

The *Inner Canon* states: “The bladder is the official of the reservoir; fluids are stored therein, and through qi transformation, they are expelled.” To the right lies the passage through which the large intestine expels its dregs. Of the five viscera’s true essence, only the kidneys serve as the root. When the kidneys are deficient, water is insufficient. Many resort to drying medicines, unaware of their harm, yet nothing surpasses nourishing them with flavors to supplement their essence. Alas, the lungs as the yin mother are now made clear. Having thoroughly examined the principles of the viscera and bowels, one may observe the reflections of the five viscera upon the back’s transport points, discerning the pathways of life and death. This is the sage’s method of reversing the Yellow River’s flow. Only by practicing this formula can one attain the principle of longevity.

Observe the fourteenth vertebra below, on either side at a distance of one *cun* and five *fen*, where the two kidneys reside. Each is enveloped in yellow fat as a single mass, with two connecting bands serving as the kidneys’ great meridians. Passing behind the *Pingyi* point and beneath the spine, there lies a large bone at the spine’s end, roughly half a hand in size. Between them lie two points, the kidneys’ meridians. These ascend along the spine to the *Niwan* and *Naohu* within the brain—the sea of marrow. Should one master this art of circulation, preventing reckless leakage and reversing the flow to reach the *Niwan*, it becomes the Great Elixir, enabling longevity and enduring vision.

This Dao was attained by the Yellow Emperor, who thereby ascended to heaven. Later, Anqi Sheng lived for three thousand years, and Peng Zu for eight hundred, as recorded in the *Biographies of Divine Transcendents*. Thus, both ascension and extended life in the world are possible. The Radiant Master’s external elixir elucidates the subtle and profound, while the internal qi illuminates the source of fetal breathing. Though the effort may not span a full decade, others marvel at one’s agelessness, for the span of life already exceeds five cycles. One feels renewed, for within the body lies the path to heaven, and upon the back, who lacks the mark of transcendence? From the *Jiaji* to the crown, this is the direct route of cultivation. Frequently swallow the Jade Fluid of the Flowery Pond, and the Primordial Lord of the Purple Palace will send it upward. Constantly ensure qi penetrates the joints, and naturally, essence will fill and the Valley Spirit will abide.

Once the external medicine’s fire is understood, the internal elixir’s reverse flow is perpetually activated. Even if a thousand years pass before we meet again, you will appear as youthful as today. Do not say the Great Dao is difficult to comprehend—it is only that the stubborn refuse to learn immortality.

Master Liu expounded the Supreme Qi Formula. Some, afflicted by illness or suffering, may scoff at it in neglect, failing to grasp its profound workings. Misapplication yields no results, and thus they dismiss it. Recently, a woman possessed by a ghost was exorcised by a Junior Master, but the ghost turned and pursued him. Fleeing past the True Lord’s hall, the Teacher immediately perceived the situation and swiftly captured the ghost’s spirit. After the exorcism, they discussed the details. On that day, a *jiazi* day, the Junior Master had dispatched the *yichou* spirit generals and soldiers, who were thus repelled. The Teacher, however, employed the *jiazi* day’s own spirit generals and soldiers, thereby capturing the ghost. Thus, in the Orthodox Unity method, even a hair’s breadth of deviation leads to such outcomes—how much more so for the qi formula, where misapplication guarantees no results, inviting scorn and neglect.

Amidst the vast expanse of scriptures, those seeking to exhaust the sources of illness find it swiftly daunting. Yet by distilling the essentials, clarifying symptoms becomes effortless upon opening the text. Is this not the very virtue of those who cultivate the body—to attain health and well-being, and to advance in the wondrous Dao of the True? How magnificent indeed!

The disciples of the True Origin School addressed the enlightened youths: To govern the heavens and punish evil, nothing surpasses transmitting the scriptures and exhorting goodness.

On the seventh day of the first lunar month in the *wuchen* year, reverently reflecting upon the Teacher, I recall how Confucius—the very paragon of the sages—still inquired of Laozi about rites and sought counsel from Chang Hong on music. How then could I, a fool, dare not honor my master? Especially when the master, in boundless benevolence, bestowed the *Scripture of Enlightenment*, which, in its essence, expounds the August Heavenly Worthy as the sovereign of the Way of ruler and minister, father and son.

Thus, when cultivated throughout the world, it speaks of the sagely ruler’s Way, prizing benevolence and love for all under heaven. When cultivated within a state, it speaks of the loyal minister’s Way, prizing reverence and obedience to superiors. When cultivated among ministers, it speaks of the Way of assisting governance, prizing respect, kindness, and righteousness. When cultivated within the family, it speaks of the filial and fraternal Way, prizing ritual, music, and harmony. When cultivated in the self, it speaks of the Way of emptiness and quiescence, prizing the preservation of harmonious qi. Only when none of these are lacking may one be deemed fit for the gate of the Wondrous True.

Next was bestowed the *Scripture of Extended Models*, which reveals the August Teaching Lord who enlightens all beings. It begins with the standards of virtue and the Five Constants, proceeds to the nurturing of harmonious qi, and concludes with the precepts for luminous illumination and abiding in the world. Through unwavering diligence, one may attain union with the palace of the Wondrous True.

Following this was the *Scripture of the True Origin*, which expounds the Lord of the True Origin, emphasizing the transformation of unwholesome traits. Through great compassion, one cultivates inner emptiness and non-action while outwardly manifesting numinous transformation for the benefit of all. Such is the practice rightly called the True Origin.

Then was granted the *Scripture of the Great Cavern*, which reveals the August Emperor of the Mysterious and Infinitesimal Heavenly Palace, unfolding the dragon-script canon of the Great Cavern and bequeathing the phoenix-records of the True Origin’s precepts. Herein lies the mystery of the Feminine One and the secrecy of the Masculine One. Heaven and Earth attain clarity and tranquility through it; the sun and moon gain their luminous radiance; yin and yang ascend and flourish; and all beings endure in harmony. Should one study the Great Cavern, mastering the wondrous existence and true non-being, and harmonizing virtue and power, one merges with the Wondrous True.

Subsequently were bestowed the *Charts and Writings of the Great Cavern* and the *Natural Chapters*, which declare that humans receive their nature from Heaven and Earth, and the Dao models itself upon spontaneity. All that has form yet lacks sentience arises from this singular source. Thus, the sage does not act before things do, nor does he precede them. Instead, he follows their natural course and extends it. As for the celestial patterns and charts, even the sun and moon adhere to their measures—how could great and small lack their proper bounds? All things that come into being possess them. Therefore, the myriad beings bear yin on their backs and embrace yang in their arms, harmonizing through the qi of the center. Those who attain harmony live; those who lose it—what can be said of them?

Finally was granted the *Scripture of the Wondrous True*, which first clarifies the Lord of the Mysterious and Infinitesimal Heaven, transmitting the non-actional Dao of the Imperial One of the Empty Cavern and Wondrous True. It then expounds the life-generating virtue of the Lord of the Jade-Conserving Heaven, who bestows the Eastern Florescence and the Wondrous Existence. Lastly, it sets forth the teachings of the Lord of the Great Vermilion Heaven, spreading the numinous non-being and the singular transformation of the Primal Human. It further regulates the twelve meridians, prizing peace, harmony, and joy. Only then may one gather the Way of wondrous existence and the lineage of true non-being. Thus, the primordial qi becomes the foundation of life and transformation, and the yang spirit the mystery of transcendence. When virtue and power are harmonized, one is called the Wondrous True.

The above scriptures and models all transform beings, swiftly correcting wrongdoing and hastening them toward the good Way. For those who leave the household to cultivate the Dao, there are exalted and enlightened masters to guide them. For those who remain in the world to revere the True, are there not the celestial teachings to instruct them?

The Buddhist verse:
*Bright moon divides its form, ever renewed in every place,*
*Can the white-robed fall behind those who comprehend emptiness?*
*Who says the laity hinder the cultivation of the Dao?*
*Golden Grain once took the form of the Elder’s body.*

When grasped in the heart, the foul *ilan* becomes the sandalwood tree. When the essence is lost, even nectar turns to a garden of thorns and brambles.

The *Dongbin* verse:
*Rolling waves of desire, who will board the immortal’s ferry?*
*The Dao lies hidden, nameless—yet the body abides in the Dao.*
*Dual principles □ the principle—this is called the True Origin.*

Thus, those who grasp the essentials may conclude with a single word. Those who do not know the essentials scatter endlessly.

Alas! Many revere the Dao without thought, yet few encounter its truth. How lamentable that the few who err may yet be corrected, but when the many err, none can be saved. What is to be done?

Even the Teaching Lord, though noble as the Son of Heaven, deeply mourned this. How much more so for the ignorant—how could they attain realization? Yet the wise and enlightened, though they may stumble, need only glimpse the Wondrous True Dao to perceive it with luminous clarity, following the path of the ranked immortals. Should one encounter it, one must strive with utmost diligence.

A sojourner in the land of Great Liang, once reduced to beggary, on the *zhengyuan* day of the *wuchen* year, received from the master these scriptures in their entirety. Yet I marveled at their completeness, and in transcribing them, errors crept into the seal script. From afar, I yearn for the recovery of these texts. May the noble scholars correct and encourage, for such is the way of tireless instruction—would this not be fitting?

Long ago, on the *shangyuan* day of the *jiazi* year, while engaged in purification rites at the True Origin Abbey, the August Heavenly Emperor of the Dark Mystery suddenly descended, delivering a divine pronouncement: "The precious precepts of the Wondrous True originated with Emperor Yao and are the incarnate response of the Heavenly Worthy of the Dao and Virtue from the Upper Realm. They may be transmitted to the virtuous; this foolish old man has benefited greatly." With reverence, I bathed and recorded this, tracing its source and intent, wishing to elucidate its teachings.

Those who possess incomplete or defective versions of the *Daoist Canon* shall not accept them. Thus, I have distilled its essentials, pruned its redundancies, and devoted this work to the lofty scholars of the Mysterious Dao. Upon perusal, may they advance in the Way with clarity and strive without hesitation.

I have learned that the Wondrous Non-Ultimate Supreme Emperor initiated the Great Cavern’s Mysterious Truth, first bestowing the title of Jade Clarity’s Celestial Lord, Master of the Teachings of Equal Heaven, to propagate the wind of the Dao and illuminate virtue, and to chastise evil while exhorting goodness. In this latter age, disciples fortunate enough to encounter such rare treasures seek to repay their masters’ benevolence—no endeavor surpasses the expansion of the scriptural model. To cultivate one’s own perfection alone, delighting solely in the Three Caverns, how does this compare to sharing its bounty widely across the nine directions, that all may together bathe in the Mysterious Blessing? This is the sincere aspiration of my heart.

Disciple of the True Origin, your servant Li Jingyuan, declares: With reverence, I have received the soaring decree of the Protector Sage. As in the time of Emperor Yao, this is the incarnate response of the Heavenly Worthy of the Dao and Virtue from the Upper Realm. Here lies the Wondrous True Precious Text, now reproduced in print by the reclusive scholar of Liang. After purificatory rites and offerings at the shrine, I submit this memorial, further entreating that it be distributed among booksellers, ensuring its transmission throughout the commanderies. May all, in emulation, chastise evil and exhort goodness, aligning with the Heavenly Dao.

With humble devotion, this solitary servant seeks to exhaust his sincerity, dedicating these meritorious virtues to the august sovereign emperor of the great dynasty, praying for his boundless longevity. May the crown prince enjoy countless years, and may the various princes, ministers, and aides likewise attain enduring lifespans, sharing in the fortune of eternal peace. Thus concludes the *Sequel to the Profound Source of the Dao and the Cavern of True Mystery*.

chunks.original_text: 渊源道妙洞真继篇 经名：渊源道妙洞真继篇。 宋李景元注。 三卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》太玄部。 渊源道妙洞真继篇上 真元门生李景元集解 或问经络。 刘子曰：贵哉人躬，手少阳三焦经络，病证源流掣治。 大矣。 道运妙真，自古及今。 故善言古者，必有证於今； 善言天者，必有验於人。 惟天之节气一十有二，人之经络以应之； 周天度数三百六十有五，人之气穴以应之。 言人之九窍五藏十二节，谓手足阴阳各三焉。 皆通乎天气时乎。 斗柄方回，寅之泰卦，律中太簇，肇当孟春之月。 古以子为元，今以寅为首，则天道南行，其象在上为人马官，在下为燕，其气专在人之三焦。 三焦者，次渎之官，水道出焉。 属膀胱是孤之府也。 言心与肺，同处上焦，上焦如雾； 次肝与脾，共处中焦，中焦如涯； 又其次肾位，处下焦，下焦如渎。 三焦者，水谷之道路，神气之终始也。 上焦者，在心下，下鬲在胃口上，主内而不出，其治在擅中玉堂下，直两乳问陷者是。 中焦者，在胃中院，不上不下，主腐熟水谷，其治在脐旁，日天枢。 下焦者，在脐下，当膀胱上口，主分别清浊，主出而不内，以传道也。 其治在脐下一寸，名日三焦，其府在气冲。 气冲在腹脐下，横骨两端，鼠既上，同身寸之一寸。 动豚应手，三焦六气变化，但诸脉皆所出。 为井金关冲，二穴在手小指次指之端，去爪甲如韭叶。 所流为荣水液门，二穴在手小指支指陷中。 所注为脸木中渚，二穴在手小指次指本节后间。 三焦俞在第十三椎下，两傍三焦之募，在脐下同身之寸二寸，名日丹田。 所过为原阳池，二穴在手表腕上陷中。 以诸经络，皆以俞为原，在脐下肾间。 动气者，人之生命也，诸经之根本尔，故名日原。 所行为经火支沟，二穴在手腕后三寸，两骨之间。 每夜乾时，人气所在，手少阳三焦经，竖者为经。 及乎玄时，人气亦在三焦络，支而横者为络。 甲主左手之少阳，其气在胆，属中焦。 寅者，正月主左足之少阳，及乎人气在左，亦在於肝。 所入为合土天井，二穴在豚外大骨之后肘上一寸陷中。 三焦，手少阳之豚，起于小指次指之端，上出两指之间，循手表出臂外两骨之问，上贯肘循燸外上肩，而交出足少阳之后，入缺盆布擅中，散络心包下膈，循属三焦。 三焦病者，腹气满，小腹尤坚，不得小便，窘急溢则水留。 上焦者，在心下膈，在胃上口，主内而不出，其治在擅中玉堂下一寸六分，直两乳问陷者是。 中焦者，在中院，不上不下，主腐熟水谷，其治在脐傍，脐下一寸，名曰三焦。 下焦者，在脐下，当膀胱上口，主分别清浊，主出溅而不内，以传道也，其治在脐下一寸，名曰三焦。 其府在气冲，几乎丹田，上焦募也，在脐下同身寸之二寸。 上焦虚寒论曰：三焦如雾，其气起於胃上口，并咽已上贯膈，其气虚寒，则令人精神不守。 引气於肺，欬嗽语声不出，膈寒之病生焉。 上焦热结论曰：上焦在心下，其气起於胃上口，并咽贯膈有热，则喉舌乾燥，口气面赤，胸膈否满之病生焉。 中焦虚寒论曰：中焦如涯者，以其在胃中院，不上不下，主腐热水谷，本胃院之阳气。 温乃能腐化水谷之精，灌养周身。 若寒，客中位，则胃中玲，胃中玲则饮食不化，腹痛飧泄霍乱吐利，治法宜温补之。

**Profound Source of the Dao’s Mysteries: Continuation of the Cavern of True Reality**
*Scripture Title:* *Profound Source of the Dao’s Mysteries: Continuation of the Cavern of True Reality*
Annotated by Li Jingyuan of the Song Dynasty
Three scrolls
Source text: *Daoist Canon of the Orthodox Tradition*, Supreme Mystery Section

**Profound Source of the Dao’s Mysteries: Continuation of the Cavern of True Reality, Scroll One**
Compiled and annotated by Li Jingyuan, disciple of the Gate of True Origin

**Question on the Meridians and Collaterals**
Master Liu states: How noble is the human body! The hand Shaoyang Triple Burner meridians and collaterals—with their patterns of disease, origins, progression, and treatment—are vast indeed.

The Dao’s operation through wondrous reality spans from antiquity to the present. Thus, one who speaks well of the past must find verification in the present; one who speaks well of Heaven must find confirmation in humanity. The celestial divisions of qi number twelve, to which the human meridians correspond; the degrees of the celestial circuit total three hundred and sixty-five, to which the human qi points correspond. The nine orifices, five viscera, and twelve joints of the human body—referring to the three yin and three yang of the hands and feet—all communicate with Heaven’s qi and respond to the seasons.

When the Dipper’s handle turns, the *Tai* hexagram of the *yin* position marks the onset of the first lunar month, and the pitch standard aligns with *Taicou*. The ancient system took *zi* as the origin, but now *yin* is regarded as the beginning. Thus, the celestial Dao moves southward: its image above is the Human and Horse constellations, and below, the Swallow. Its qi concentrates in the human Triple Burner.

The Triple Burner is the official of the waterways, from which the water passages emerge. It pertains to the Bladder, the solitary *fu*. The Heart and Lungs reside together in the Upper Burner, which is like mist; the Liver and Spleen share the Middle Burner, which is like a marsh; and the Kidneys occupy the Lower Burner, which is like a drainage ditch. The Triple Burner is the thoroughfare of water and grain, the beginning and end of the spirit and qi.

The Upper Burner lies below the Heart and above the diaphragm, at the upper opening of the Stomach. It governs intake but not discharge, and its treatment point is one *cun* and six *fen* below the *Shanzhong* (Jade Hall), in the depression between the two nipples. The Middle Burner lies in the central region of the Stomach, neither above nor below, governing the decomposition of water and grain. Its treatment point is beside the navel, called *Tianshu*. The Lower Burner lies below the navel, at the upper opening of the Bladder, governing the separation of the clear and turbid, discharge but not intake, and the transmission of waste. Its treatment point is one *cun* below the navel, named *Sanjiao* (Triple Burner), and its *fu* is at *Qichong*. *Qichong* is located below the navel, at the two ends of the pubic bone, one *cun* above the groin, where the pulsation of the femoral artery responds to the hand.

The transformations of the Triple Burner’s six qi all emanate from the meridians. The well points (*jing*) are Metal: *Guanchong*, two points located at the tips of the little finger and the next finger, a leek-leaf’s width from the nail. The flowing points (*rong*) are Water: *Yemen*, two points in the depression between the little finger and the next finger. The transporting points (*shu*) are Wood: *Zhongzhu*, two points behind the proximal joint of the little finger and the next finger. The Triple Burner’s *shu* point is below the thirteenth vertebra, and its *mu* point is two *cun* below the navel, called the *Dantian*. The source points (*yuan*) are *Yangchi*, two points in the depression on the dorsal wrist. All meridians take their *shu* points as their source, located between the Kidneys below the navel. The moving qi is the life of the human being, the root of all meridians—hence it is called the *yuan* (source).

The channel points (*jing*) are Fire: *Zhigou*, two points three *cun* behind the wrist, between the two bones. At the *qian* hour of night, the human qi resides in the hand Shaoyang Triple Burner meridian; the vertical vessels are the *jing* (channels). By the *xu* hour, the human qi also lies in the Triple Burner’s collaterals; the horizontal vessels are the *luo* (collaterals). *Jia* governs the left hand’s Shaoyang, its qi in the Gallbladder, pertaining to the Middle Burner. *Yin*—the first month—governs the left foot’s Shaoyang, and the human qi on the left also resides in the Liver.

The uniting points (*he*) are Earth: *Tianjing*, two points in the depression one *cun* above the elbow, behind the outer bone. The Triple Burner is the hand Shaoyang meridian. It begins at the tip of the little finger and the next finger, ascends between the two fingers, follows the back of the hand, emerges between the two bones of the forearm, passes through the elbow, ascends along the outer arm to the shoulder, crosses behind the foot Shaoyang, enters the supraclavicular fossa, spreads through the *Shanzhong*, connects with the Pericardium, descends through the diaphragm, and pertains to the Triple Burner.

**Triple Burner Disorders**
When the Triple Burner is diseased, the abdomen becomes full, the lower abdomen particularly hard, urination is obstructed, and urgency leads to overflow, causing water retention.

The Upper Burner lies below the Heart and above the diaphragm, at the upper opening of the Stomach. It governs intake but not discharge, and its treatment point is one *cun* and six *fen* below *Shanzhong* (Jade Hall), in the depression between the two nipples. The Middle Burner lies in the central region of the Stomach, neither above nor below, governing the decomposition of water and grain. Its treatment point is one *cun* below the navel, named *Sanjiao*. The Lower Burner lies below the navel, at the upper opening of the Bladder, governing the separation of the clear and turbid, discharge but not intake, and the transmission of waste. Its treatment point is one *cun* below the navel, named *Sanjiao*. Its *fu* is at *Qichong*, near the *Dantian*. The Upper Burner’s *mu* point is two *cun* below the navel.

**Discourse on Upper Burner Deficiency-Cold**
The Upper Burner is like mist. Its qi arises at the upper opening of the Stomach, ascends alongside the throat, and penetrates the diaphragm. When its qi is deficient and cold, it causes the spirit to lose its residence. Drawing qi into the Lungs, it results in coughing, loss of voice, and the onset of diaphragmatic cold disorders.

**Discourse on Upper Burner Heat**
The Upper Burner lies below the Heart. Its qi arises at the upper opening of the Stomach, ascends alongside the throat, and penetrates the diaphragm. When heat is present, it causes dryness of the throat and tongue, foul breath, flushed face, and the onset of chest and diaphragmatic fullness and stagnation.

**Discourse on Middle Burner Deficiency-Cold**
The Middle Burner is like a marsh, for it lies in the central region of the Stomach, neither above nor below, governing the decomposition of water and grain. The Stomach’s yang qi must be warm to decompose and transform the essence of water and grain, nourishing the entire body. If cold invades this central position, the Stomach becomes cold. When the Stomach is cold, food is not digested, leading to abdominal pain, undigested diarrhea, cholera, vomiting, and diarrhea. The treatment method should involve warming and supplementation.

chunks.original_text: 中焦热结论曰：中焦者，在胃中院，不上不下，主腐熟水谷，其气和平，澜能传糟粕，蒸津液变，精微上注於肺，通於荣卫，如热在中焦则为坚，故其气实则闭塞，不通上下，膈绝热外身重、目黄、目甘，脾瘴之证生焉。 下焦虚寒论曰：下焦如渎，其气起於胃下院别回肠，注於膀胱，主出而不内，以传道也。 其气虚寒，则津液不固，大小便利不止，小腹痛，不欲闻人语。 如三焦俱虚。 上焦虚，则引气於肺； 中焦虚，则生寒，腹痛、洞泄、便利、霍乱； 下焦虚，则大小便不止，津液气绝寒，则补於肾。 然三焦者，水谷之道路，气之所终始也。 其处虽异，其原则一，故有俱虚之病，治宜温之。 下焦热结论曰：下焦者，在脐下当膀胱上口，主分别清浊，出而不内，以传道也。 又下焦如渎，司次壅，泄其气，实而有热，则津液内燥，传道不利，由是有气逆、便难、胃胀、呕哕之证。 三焦统论曰：三焦有名无形，主持诸气以象三才之用，故呼吸升降，水谷往来，皆待此以通达。 是以上焦在心下，主内而不出； 中焦在胃院，主腐熟水谷； 下焦在脐下，主分别清浊，出而不内。 统而论之，三焦者上合於少阳，出於关冲。 关冲者，在手小指次指之端，是手少阳经也，太阳络也。 故三焦气盛为有余，则胀气满於皮肤内，轻轻然而不实。 或小便清，大便难。 大便难者，由五藏不调，阴阳偏有虚实，谓三焦不和，则玲热并结故也。 是为三焦之实也。 则宜以嘻掣之，掣音导三焦之气，不足则寒气客之，病遗尿，或泄利，或气满，或食不消，是三焦之气虚也。 则宜以劳官二穴，抱一关元而温之，兼闭口屈舌食其胎津可也。 劳官二穴火也，在掌中央动脉下，以屈无名指取之。 关元者，小肠募也，在脐下同身寸之三寸，足三阴任脉之会也。 天地有大美而不言，四时有明法而不议，万物有成理而不说，故天不言而四时行焉、百物生焉。 惟圣人原天地之美，达万物之理。 调理，春温，夏暑，秋忿，冬怒，四时迭运不齐也。 方阳用事，万物以熙，人於是时，以祈以因。 方阴用事，万物以凝，人於是时，以夷以噢。 况夫六化，分治五味，五色所生，五藏所宜，皆消息盈虚系焉。 攸在每岁寅卯辰月，仍为春时，春气西行，春气在经脉，故春弦如钧，脉之常也。 如不从常，反是者病，春气始於下及左。 又言春气始於前，故正月二月春气在肝，肝王於春，及王於甲乙，俞在颈项。 肝者，将军之官，谋虑出焉，魂之居也。 凡肝为发生之主，肝为少阳，阳长之始，及正月二月三月，人气在左，唯春养阳，宜食其凉，以养於阳。 肝其恶风，亦畏於清，清金令也。 凡春伤於风，夏为飧泄，故春病在肝与头及俞，亦在其阴矣。 兼春病始於前，善养生者，则於春气调神，所为夜外早起，广步於庭，被发缓形，以使志生，此春气应养生之道也。 春哄清治肝而反温，凡天之用温，可以远温，故从之则全神，逆之则伤肝。 惟斗之正建仲春之月，卯之大壮，律仲夹锺，天道西南行，其象在上为天蝎官，在下为宋，其气所在，人之大肠。 大肠者，传道之官，变化出焉。 变化之方，手阳明大肠经之井金，为商阳二穴，在手大指次指内侧，去爪甲如韭叶，荣木为二间，二穴，在手大指次指本节前内侧陷中，瑜木为三间，二穴在手大指次指本节后内康侧陷中，大肠俞在第十六椎下，两傍原为合谷，二穴在大指岐骨问陷中，一名虎口。

**Discourse on Middle Burner Heat**

The Middle Burner resides in the central region of the Stomach, neither above nor below, governing the decomposition and maturation of water and grain. Its qi is harmonious and gentle, smoothly transmitting the waste and steaming the fluids to transform them. The refined essence ascends to infuse the Lungs, circulating through the constructive and defensive qi. If heat lodges in the Middle Burner, it congeals into hardness, causing its qi to become replete and obstructed, failing to communicate between above and below. The diaphragm becomes severed by heat, the exterior of the body grows heavy, the eyes turn yellow, and a sweet taste lingers in the mouth—thus arise the signs of spleen obstruction.

**Discourse on Lower Burner Deficiency-Cold**

The Lower Burner is like a drainage ditch. Its qi arises from the lower region of the Stomach, diverging at the turning intestine and pouring into the Bladder. It governs outward movement without inward retention, serving as the pathway of transmission. If its qi is deficient and cold, the fluids are not secured, leading to incessant diarrhea of both stool and urine, lower abdominal pain, and aversion to hearing human speech. Should all Three Burners be deficient: Upper Burner deficiency draws qi into the Lungs; Middle Burner deficiency generates cold, giving rise to abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, incessant bowel movements, and cholera; Lower Burner deficiency results in unceasing stool and urine, the severance of fluids and qi, and cold—thus supplementation should target the Kidneys. Now, the Three Burners are the pathways of water and grain, the beginning and end of qi. Though their locations differ, their principle is one, hence the existence of diseases where all are deficient. The treatment should involve warming.

**Discourse on Lower Burner Heat**

The Lower Burner lies below the navel, at the upper opening of the Bladder, governing the separation of the clear and turbid. It moves outward without inward retention, serving as the pathway of transmission. Moreover, the Lower Burner is like a drainage ditch, managing the dredging and discharge of qi. If it is replete and harbors heat, the fluids within desiccate, and transmission becomes impeded—thus arise signs of qi counterflow, difficult defecation, abdominal distension, and retching. The treatment method should involve draining and guiding the qi of the Three Burners.

**Comprehensive Discourse on the Three Burners**

The Three Burners have a name but no form, presiding over all qi to emulate the functions of the Three Powers. Thus, the ascent and descent of breath, the coming and going of water and grain, all depend on this for free passage. Therefore, the Upper Burner lies below the Heart, governing inward retention without outward discharge; the Middle Burner lies in the Stomach region, governing the decomposition and maturation of water and grain; the Lower Burner lies below the navel, governing the separation of the clear and turbid, moving outward without inward retention. In comprehensive discussion, the Three Burners correspond above to the Lesser Yang, emerging at Guanchong. Guanchong is located at the tip of the ring finger on the hand, belonging to the Hand Lesser Yang channel, a network vessel of the Greater Yang. When the qi of the Three Burners is exuberant and in excess, distension and fullness fill the space within the skin, feeling light yet unsubstantial. Alternatively, the urine may be clear while defecation is difficult. Difficult defecation arises from disharmony among the Five Viscera, where yin and yang are unevenly deficient or replete—this is called disharmony of the Three Burners, where cold and heat congeal together. This is the repletion of the Three Burners, and the appropriate method is to guide and drain their qi. If the qi of the Three Burners is insufficient, cold qi invades, causing enuresis, diarrhea, qi fullness, or undigested food—this is the deficiency of the Three Burners’ qi. The appropriate method is to warm Laogong and Guanyuan, embracing unity and securing the Origin, while closing the mouth, curling the tongue, and swallowing the fetal fluids. Laogong, a Fire point, lies below the pulsation in the center of the palm; it is located by bending the ring finger to find it. Guanyuan, the alarm point of the Small Intestine, lies three body-inches below the navel, at the convergence of the Foot Three Yin and the Conception Vessel.

Heaven possesses great beauty yet does not speak; the four seasons have bright laws yet do not debate; the myriad things have completed principles yet do not explain. Thus, Heaven does not speak, yet the four seasons proceed and the hundred things are born. Only the sage traces the beauty of Heaven and Earth, penetrating the principles of the myriad things. In regulation, spring is warm, summer is hot, autumn is sharp, winter is stern—the four seasons alternate in succession without uniformity. When yang is in operation, the myriad things flourish; at such times, people seek and follow. When yin is in operation, the myriad things congeal; at such times, people become tranquil and sigh. Moreover, the six transformations govern the five flavors, the generation of the five colors, and the suitability for the Five Viscera—all are tied to the waxing and waning of growth and decline.

In each year, the months of *yin*, *mao*, and *chen* constitute springtime. Spring qi moves westward, residing in the channels and vessels—thus, in spring, the pulse is taut like a hook, which is the norm. If it does not follow the norm but deviates, it is pathological. Spring qi begins below and to the left. It is also said that spring qi begins in the front; thus, in the first and second months, spring qi resides in the Liver. The Liver governs in spring and flourishes in *jia* and *yi*, with its transport point in the neck and nape. The Liver is the organ of the general, whence plans and deliberations emerge; it is the abode of the ethereal soul. The Liver is the master of generation, the Lesser Yang, the beginning of yang’s growth. In the first, second, and third months, human qi resides on the left. To nourish yang in spring, one should consume cooling foods to cultivate yang. The Liver detests wind and also fears clarity—clarity is the command of Metal. If spring is injured by wind, summer will bring watery diarrhea. Thus, spring diseases reside in the Liver, the head, and the transport points, as well as in its yin aspect. Moreover, spring diseases begin in the front. Those skilled in nurturing life regulate their spirit in accordance with spring qi: retiring late and rising early, strolling broadly in the courtyard, loosening the hair and relaxing the body to enliven the will—this is the Way of nurturing life in response to spring qi. Spring should be cool to govern the Liver, but if it is warm instead, one should distance oneself from warmth, for following this preserves the spirit, while opposing it injures the Liver.

In the month when the Dipper’s handle points due east, the second month of spring, *mao* is in the phase of *Great Strength*. The pitch standard is *Zhonglü*, the celestial path moves southwest, its image above is the Celestial Scorpion Palace, below is Song. Its qi resides in the human Large Intestine. The Large Intestine is the organ of transmission, whence transformations emerge. The method of transformation: the Metal well point of the Hand Yangming Large Intestine channel is Shangyang, two points located on the inner side of the index finger, a leek-leaf’s width from the corner of the nail; the Wood spring point is Erjian, two points in the depression on the inner side of the index finger’s proximal joint; the Wood transport point is Sanjian, two points in the depression on the inner side of the index finger’s distal joint; the Large Intestine transport point is below the sixteenth vertebra, on either side; the source point is Hegu, two points in the depression between the thumb and index finger, also called the Tiger’s Mouth.

The summer pulse is surging and large—this is its normal state. If it deviates from this norm, it indicates disease.

From the fourth month of summer onward, human qi is on the right and pertains to the spleen. In the fifth and sixth months, qi similarly resides on the right and pertains to the head. Summer’s heat resides in the heart. Heat injures the form, so the heart dislikes heat and fears cold. Cold is the mandate of water, and thus using heat at the right time can keep heat at bay. Medicinals and food should follow the same principle. Therefore, the wise avoid compounding heat with heat. If one does not keep heat at a distance, heat will arrive. When heat arrives, it causes fever, vomiting, diarrhea, cholera, abscesses, sores, mental confusion, depression, diarrhea with urgency, spasms, swelling, distension, vomiting, nosebleeds, headaches, bone and joint pain, muscle soreness, blood overflow, blood in the stool, and urinary strangury.

Thus, tranquility is attained. If one suffers from illness, there exists the Dao of regulating the spirit in accordance with summer qi. This entails retiring late and rising early, never tiring of the sun, ensuring the mind remains free from anger, and allowing qi to flow freely. Such is the Dao of nurturing growth in response to summer qi. To contravene this injures the heart.

When the Dipper’s handle points due south in the mid-summer month, it aligns with the *Gou* hexagram of the noon position, and the pitch corresponds to *Ruibin*. Noon marks the meridian, where the *Initial Six* yin begins to stir. The celestial Dao moves northwest, its image above in the constellation of the Lion, below in the Zhou region. Human qi resides in the heart, which governs the five viscera.

The heart is the zang-organ, the small intestine its paired fu-organ. Its nature is summerheat, which harms the form. Its note is *zhi*, its image *Li*. Fire reigns in summer, is cut off in winter, and perishes under the *ren* and *gui* stems. Thus, the human heart-mind responds to the eight winds:

When wind comes from the east, it is called *Infant Wind*. It injures the outer sinews and twists, lodging internally in the liver.
When wind comes from the southeast, it is called *Weak Wind*. It injures the outer flesh, lodging internally in the stomach.
When wind comes from the south, it is called *Great Weak Wind*. It injures the outer vessels, lodging internally in the heart.
When wind comes from the southwest, it is called *Plotting Wind*. It injures the outer muscles, lodging internally in the spleen.
When wind comes from the west, it is called *Sturdy Wind*. It injures the outer skin, lodging internally in the lungs.
When wind comes from the northwest, it is called *Breaking Wind*. It injures the *Taiyang* vessels of the hand, connecting internally to the small intestine.
When wind comes from the north, it is called *Great Sturdy Wind*. It injures the outer bones, lodging internally in the kidneys.
When wind comes from the northeast, it is called *Ominous Wind*. It injures the outer flanks and ribs, lodging internally in the large intestine.

Thus, the human heart-mind responds to the eight winds. For the qi of life communicates with Heaven—no small matter indeed.

The heart stores the spirit, which delights in serenity and emptiness. The heart is the sovereign official, the yang father. The external aspect of the heart is yang. As the root of life and the transformation of spirit, the heart is where the numinous luminosity emerges. Its luster manifests in the complexion, its fullness in the blood vessels. The vessels are the mansion of blood, where all blood converges under the heart’s governance.

Prolonged gazing injures the blood, for it wearies the heart. When the heart is wearied, one becomes absent-minded, forgetful, and suffers from difficult bowel movements—sometimes loose like duck droppings—or mouth sores. Grief, sorrow, and excessive contemplation injure the heart, leading to fright, forgetfulness, and erratic joy or anger.

The heart is yang qi, the supreme yang within yang. Yang diseases arise in the blood. The heart nourishes blood, and thus the vessels are the foundation of the five viscera. The heart governs the vessels, which course through the arms and hands. The heart opens into the ears, the anterior and posterior yin orifices. When essence and qi converge in the heart, joy arises. Thus, sudden joy injures the yang, the heart, and qi.

The heart’s fluid is sweat. The heart qi governs the tongue, its condition reflected there. Only when heart qi is harmonious does it communicate with the tongue. When the heart is at peace, the tongue discerns the five flavors. Its odor is scorched. A supple tongue indicates vitality; roughness, stiffness, or contraction foretell death.

The heart desires bitter flavors, which enter it first. Excessive bitter flavors cause the skin to wither and the hair to fall out. The heart desires softness; to soften it, consume salty foods promptly. The heart suffers from slackness; to restrain it, consume sour foods promptly. The heart loathes heat and fears cold, for cold is the mandate of water.

Excessive bitter flavors fail to moisten the spleen qi, thickening the stomach qi—this is a forbidden flavor. Salt travels to the blood; in blood diseases, avoid excessive salt. The heart’s prohibitions are warm clothing and hot food.

Thus, the sage approaches sounds, colors, and flavors: what benefits nature is embraced, what harms it is discarded. When food and drink enter the stomach, they nourish the heart zang. When the heart flourishes, the complexion mirrors the sun. Thus, in heart heat, the forehead reddens first.

It is said that heart heat manifests as redness with overflowing vessels. If the complexion is predominantly green, there is pain; if black, numbness; if yellow-red, heat; if white, cold. When all five colors appear, there is both cold and heat. Though red and yellow signify heat, green, white, and black portend misfortune—how can one remain ignorant?

The southern direction is ruled by red qi, which fills the body with resonant sound, like wind and thunder. In humans, the heart stores sound, manifesting as laughter and mirth. Such is the heart at peace. If the heart is not at peace, the voice alters, and illness arises as hiccups, belching, or sorrow.

As the sovereign, the father, and the master of the five qi, the heart governs qi, vessels, sound, and color. The heart zang transforms in myriad ways: generation is called *transformation*; extremity, *change*.

The *Hand Shaoyin* is the heart’s meridian. Its *Jing-Well* point is *Shaochong*, two points located on the inner corner of the little finger, a leek-leaf’s width from the nail. Its *Ying-Spring* point is *Shaofu*, two points in the depression behind the little finger’s proximal joint. Its *Shu-Stream* point is *Shenmen*, two points at the ulnar end of the wrist crease; if the pulse here is imperceptible, death is untreatable.

The heart’s *Back-Shu* point lies below the fifth vertebra, bilateral to the spine, one and a half body-inches apart—the meeting of *Taiyang*. The heart’s *Yuan-Source* point emerges at *Daling*, flowing into the pericardium meridian. Its *Jing-River* point is *Lingdao*, two points one and a half inches (or one inch) proximal to the wrist crease.

At the *bing* hour of midday, human qi resides in the *Hand Shaoyin*, the heart’s meridian. At the *wu* hour, qi also dwells in the heart’s network vessels.

chunks.original_text: 丁主右手之阳明，其气亦主心藏之疾。 午者为经，五月主右足之太阳，兼人气在右，亦在於头。 合水为少海，二穴在肘内臁节后陷中。 手少阴，心之脉，起於心中，出属心系。 下膈络小肠，心之平脉，洪大为常，沈为贼脉，厥疾生焉。 心气暑热，心藏血脉之气，若邪气在心则病，心痛、喜悲、时眩、仆心。 其病之在於脉气及乎五藏。 故心病者，胸中痛，胁支满，胁下痛，膺背肩甲问痛，两臂内痛，是以心病侯者。 心象火。 王於夏，其脉如钩而洪大，其侯舌，其声言，其臭焦，其味苦，其液汗，其养血，其色赤，而藏神手少阴其经也。 与小肠合，小肠为府而主表，心为藏而主裹。 心气盛为神，有余则病。 胸内痛，胁支满，胁下痛，膺背肩胛两臂间痛，喜笑不休，是心气之实也。 实则生热，热则阳气盛，阳气盛则荣卫之气不能通行，心神烦乱，面赤身热，口舌生疮，咽燥头痛，热多则筋□，骨消肉烁，□破毛直而败。 或言：阳气有余，阴气不足，则热中。 善饥，心气不足，则胸气大胁下，与腰背相引而痛，惊悸恍惚，少颜色，舌本强，善忧悲，是为心气之虚也。 心之统论：心与小肠合，故手少阴经与手太阳经为表裹，其象火，其王夏，其脉洪，在藏为神，在志为喜，在变动为忧，在液为汗。 是故心气虚，即悲不已，实则笑不休。 心气虚则梦救火，阳物得其时则梦燔灼。 心气盛则梦喜笑恐畏厥。 气客於心则梦丘山烟火。 心衰则健忘。 心热则多汗。 心热病者，先不乐数日乃热，热争则卒，心痛烦闷，善呕，头面赤，无汗。 气逆者，厥也。 谓阴阳二气卒有衰绝，逆於常度。 若阴气衰绝，於下则为热厥。 如阳气衰绝，於下则为寒厥。 虚则生寒，寒情绪不乐，或悲不已，心腹暴痛，唾清涎，喜忘，多惊。 寒多则筋挛骨痛，及乎凝泣。 有言心神不足及乎脉气不足，而形气有余者则死。 或言阳气不足，阴气有余，则寒中，肠呜腹痛。 若阴阳俱有余，俱不足，则有寒有热。 故诸痛痒疮疡，皆属於心。 诸热瞀瘛，皆属於火。 诸禁鼓栗，如丧神守，皆属於火。 诸逆冲上，皆属於火。 诸躁狂越，皆属於火。 诸病胕肿疼酸惊骇，皆属於火。 诸胀腹大，皆属於热。 诸病有声，鼓之如鼓，皆属於热。 诸转反戾，水液浑浊，皆属於热。 诸呕吐酸暴注下迫，皆属於热，故热胜则肿结。 阳者肿四支，四支为诸阳之本。 凡人之温热者，疮汗之。 则疮已热之，则风生。 故心风而口赤及乎皮剥。 以夏丙丁伤於风者为心风。 心风之状，多汗、恶风、焦绝、喜怒，吓赤色。 病甚则言不可快，诊在口，其色赤。 惟有道者则不热，如心偶虚，宜用药食味酸者，以补之。 及乎实者，则用味甘者以泻之。 专进□气之方，呵以治之，但病疹即已，不可过尔。 抑又再建季夏之月，未之遁卦，律中林锺。 言人气应音，人阴阳合气应律。 天道东行，其象在上为巨蟹宫，在下为秦，其气在人之肺。 肺为藏，大肠为府，象金，其性清凉，其音商。 王於秋，绝於夏，死於丙丁，养於皮毛。 肺贵冲虚，主和气之源，为诸藏之长。 心之华盖，体之阴母。 又为阴中之少阴，阴藏之初，亦为相传之官，治节出焉。 故肺者，气之本，魄之处也。 专行荣卫，阴阳荣行，脉中血也。
