The *ding* stem governs the *Yangming* of the right hand, and its qi also governs the heart’s visceral diseases. The *wu* branch is the meridian; in the fifth month, it governs the *Taiyang* of the right foot, while human qi also resides on the right, dwelling in the head. The *Water* confluence is *Shaohai*, two points in the depression behind the inner elbow joint.

The *Hand Shaoyin*, the heart’s meridian, arises within the heart and emerges to connect with the heart’s system. It descends through the diaphragm to network with the small intestine. The heart’s balanced pulse is normally surging and large; if sunken, it is a predatory pulse, and reversal disorders arise.

When summer heat invades the heart, the heart stores the qi of blood and vessels. If pathogenic qi lodges in the heart, illness follows: heart pain, melancholy, frequent dizziness, and fainting. Its diseases affect the vessels’ qi and the five viscera.

Thus, when the heart is diseased: pain in the chest, fullness in the flanks, pain beneath the flanks, pain in the breast, back, shoulders, and scapulae, and pain along the inner arms—these are the signs of heart disease. The heart corresponds to Fire. It flourishes in summer; its pulse is hooking and surging, its diagnostic sign is the tongue, its sound is speech, its odor is scorched, its flavor is bitter, its fluid is sweat, it nourishes blood, its color is red, and it stores the spirit. The *Hand Shaoyin* is its meridian. It pairs with the small intestine, which is the *Fu* governing the exterior, while the heart is the *Zang* governing the interior.

When heart qi is abundant, it becomes spirit; if excessive, it causes illness. Pain within the chest, fullness in the flanks, pain beneath the flanks, pain in the breast, back, shoulders, scapulae, and between the arms, and incessant laughter—these are signs of heart qi excess. Excess generates heat; heat causes yang qi to flourish, and when yang qi flourishes, the qi of *ying* and *wei* cannot circulate. The heart spirit becomes restless, the face flushes, the body grows hot, sores appear in the mouth and on the tongue, the throat dries, the head aches. If heat is severe, the sinews wither, bones dissolve, flesh melts, the skin cracks, and hair stands on end and decays.

Some say: when yang qi is excessive and yin qi insufficient, there is heat in the center. One is prone to hunger. When heart qi is insufficient, the chest expands, the flanks and lower back pull taut with pain, there is fright, palpitations, absentmindedness, pallor, stiffness at the root of the tongue, and frequent sorrow—these are signs of heart qi deficiency.

A general discussion of the heart: The heart pairs with the small intestine, so the *Hand Shaoyin* meridian and the *Hand Taiyang* meridian form an exterior-interior relationship. It corresponds to Fire, flourishes in summer, its pulse is surging, it governs the spirit among the viscera, joy among the emotions, sorrow in its pathological movements, and sweat among the fluids. Thus, when heart qi is deficient, sorrow is unceasing; when excessive, laughter is unending. When heart qi is deficient, one dreams of rescuing from fire; when yang things prevail, one dreams of burning. When heart qi is abundant, one dreams of joy, laughter, fear, and reversal. When qi invades the heart, one dreams of mountains and flames. When the heart declines, one becomes forgetful. When the heart is hot, one sweats excessively.

In heart heat disease, one first feels dispirited for several days before heat arises. When heat contends, there is sudden heart pain, vexation, oppression, frequent retching, redness of the face, and absence of sweat. When qi rebels, there is reversal—a sudden decline or severance of yin and yang qi, disrupting their normal order. If yin qi declines and severs below, it becomes heat reversal. If yang qi declines and severs below, it becomes cold reversal.

Deficiency generates cold: one feels dispirited, sorrowful, or endlessly grieving, experiences sudden pain in the heart and abdomen, spits clear saliva, is forgetful, and easily startled. If cold is severe, the sinews contract, the bones ache, and there is congealing and weeping. Some say: when heart spirit is insufficient and vessel qi deficient, yet form and qi are excessive, death follows. Or when yang qi is insufficient and yin qi excessive, there is cold in the center, borborygmi, and abdominal pain. If both yin and yang are excessive or both insufficient, there is both cold and heat.

Thus, all pain, itching, and sores belong to the heart. All heat, clouded vision, and convulsions belong to Fire. All lockjaw, chattering teeth, and loss of spirit as if bereft belong to Fire. All counterflow rushing upward belongs to Fire. All restlessness, mania, and transgression belong to Fire. All swelling, pain, soreness, fright, and alarm belong to Fire. All distension and abdominal enlargement belong to heat. All diseases with sounds like drumming belong to heat. All twisting, contortion, and turbid fluids belong to heat. All vomiting, sourness, sudden diarrhea, and urgent descent belong to heat. Thus, when heat prevails, swelling and binding occur. Yang causes swelling in the four limbs, for the four limbs are the root of all yang.

In all people, warmth and heat are treated by sweating. If sores are treated with heat, wind arises. Thus, heart wind causes redness of the mouth and peeling skin. When *bing* and *ding* days in summer are injured by wind, it is heart wind. The signs of heart wind: excessive sweating, aversion to wind, scorched dryness, frequent anger, and a red complexion. In severe cases, speech becomes incoherent. The diagnosis lies in the mouth, and its color is red. Only those who follow the Dao remain unheated. If the heart is occasionally deficient, sour flavors in medicines and foods should be used to supplement it. If excessive, sweet flavors should be used to drain it. Specialized methods for regulating qi should employ exhalation to treat it, but once the disease is cured, one must not overdo it.

Moreover, in the late summer month, the *Dun* hexagram of *Wei* governs, and the pitch corresponds to *Linzhong*. Human qi responds to sound, and human yin and yang qi harmonize with the pitch. The celestial Dao moves eastward; its image above is the constellation Cancer, and below it is Qin. Its qi resides in the human lung.

The lung is the *Zang*, the large intestine the *Fu*. It corresponds to Metal, its nature is cool and clear, its note is *shang*. It flourishes in autumn, is severed in summer, dies on *bing* and *ding* days, and is nourished in the skin and hair. The lung values emptiness and tranquility, governs the source of harmonious qi, and is the chief of all viscera. It is the canopy of the heart and the yin mother of the body. It is also the *Shaoyin* within yin, the first of the yin viscera, and the ministerial official from which governance and regulation emerge. Thus, the lung is the root of qi and the dwelling of the *po*. It alone circulates *ying* and *wei*; *ying* circulates within the vessels as blood.

The lung’s qi is cool and clear; the lung circulates *ying* and *wei*, and *ying* is the blood within yin and yang.

It is said that when essence and qi converge in the lung, sorrow arises. It is also said that joy and anger injure the qi. If evil qi resides in the lung, coughing moves the shoulders and back. The Foot Greater Yang Bladder Channel begins at the inner canthus of the eye, ascends to the forehead, and intersects at the vertex. Its straight course enters from the vertex to bind the brain, then emerges and descends along the nape, following the inner aspect of the scapula to parallel the spine, reaching the lumbar region and traveling through the sacrum to bind the kidneys.

The kidneys pertain to the bladder. When the bladder is diseased, the lower abdomen becomes unilaterally swollen and painful; pressing it induces an urge to urinate that cannot be fulfilled. Heat in the shoulders, sunken pulse, and heat along the lateral aspect of the little toe, calf, and posterior ankle—all indicate the exhaustion of fluids and humors.

The essences of the five grains and five flavors all converge in the bladder. Through qi transformation, they enter the blood vessels to form bone marrow, while the surplus of fluids and humors enters the bladder to become urine.

When its qi is exuberant and in excess, heat arises as disease. If the bladder is obstructed and urine cannot pass, with unilateral swelling and pain in the lower abdomen, this is bladder qi repletion—it should be drained. When the bladder is deficient, cold ensues; if cold qi invades, the bladder becomes slippery, and urination becomes frequent and copious. A black complexion indicates bladder qi deficiency—it should be supplemented.

The *Discourse on Bladder Deficiency and Cold* states: The bladder is the *fu* of fluids and humors. When qi transforms, they can be discharged. If its qi is insufficient, deficiency arises, and deficiency invites cold qi to exploit it, causing fluids and humors to flow unchecked. Thus, the symptoms include profuse urination, severe lower abdominal pain, and pain in the nape, back, lumbar region, sacrum, popliteal fossa, and [omitted]. It flourishes in spring and in the days of *Jia* and *Yi*, wanes in autumn, and perishes in *Geng* and *Xin*. The liver is the official of the general, from which strategies and plans emerge. It is the dwelling of the *hun*. Its luster appears in the nails, its filling in the sinews, and it generates blood and qi. Yet prolonged walking injures the sinews, straining the liver.

When the liver is strained, the face and eyes become dry and dark, the mouth bitter, the spirit unsettled, and one feels fearful, unable to sleep alone, with dim vision. It is also said that great anger causes qi counterflow, injuring the liver; when the liver is injured, blood becomes scant, and the eyes darken. When the liver is diseased, pain arises beneath the ribs, radiating to the lower abdomen, and one becomes prone to anger. chunks.original_text: 青黑为痛，白为寒。 肾热则颐赤，口下为颐。 肾热者，色黑而齿枯，有言齿槁。 肾风而肌黑，及乎皮黑。 肾气通於耳，肾和则耳能闻五声矣。 肾病，其声变动，为欠阴焉。 为嚏阳也。 为呻吟战栗。 有言五藏各有精随，用而灌注於肾。 肾为都会，关司之所。 足少阴肾之经，井木为涌泉，二穴在足心陷中，屈足卷指宛宛中。 荥火为然谷，二穴在足踝前大骨下陷中。 腧土为太溪，二穴在足内踝后，跟骨上陷中。 脉绝者死，不治。 又俞在第十四椎下两傍。 肾之原出於大溪，经金为复溜，二穴在足内踝上二寸。 每昼庚时，人气所在足少阴肾之经。 及乎酉时，人气亦在肾之络。 癸主左手之少阴，其气亦主肾藏之疾。 子者，为经十一月，主左足之太阴，兼人气在左及在於肾。 合水为阴谷，二穴在足脉内辅骨后，大筋下小筋上。 足少阴之脉，循於胸少阴冬脉也。 起于小指之下，邪走足心，出於然骨之下，循内踝之后，别入跟中，以上端内，出腘内臁上股肉后，臁贯脊，属肾络膀胱。 肾之平脉，沈贼脉缓，但人脉病不足。 其形气不病而有余者，则死。 形气不足而脉气不病而有余者，则生。 盖脉主生死，其大矣哉。 凡脉之惟纲二十四种所为。 浮脉，阳也。 为热，为痛，为呕，为胀，为痞，为喘，为厥，为内结，为满不食。 脉浮之状，若水上之浮萍风中之浮云也。 芤脉，按之则无，举之来至。 故淋涩疼痛，由失血之所致。 洪脉，为胀，为满，为痛，为热，为烦。 如水之共流，波涌而陇起。 滑豚，为吐，为满，为欬，为热，为伏痰，为宿食，为蓄血，为经闭，为鬼，为血气。 俱实，故其滑若珠也。 数脉，为热，为虚，为吐，为痛，为烦渴，为烦满。 促脉，曰气，曰血，曰饮，曰食，曰痰。 故阳盛则促，阴盛则结。 弦脉，为寒，为痛，为饮，为疟，为水气，为中虚，为厥逆，为拘急，为寒癖。 举之无有，如张弓弦。 紧脉，为寒，为痛头骨肉等，为欬，为喘。 故诸紧为寒，如切绳状。 沈脉，为实为水，为寒为喘，为症为瘕。 伏脉，为霍乱，为疝瘕，为水气，为溏泄，为停痰宿食，为诸气上冲，为恶脓贯肌。 濡脉，为虚，为痹，为自汗，为气弱，为下重濡而弱，为内热外冷自污，为小便难。 革脉，为满，为急，为虚寒相搏革改也。 去故也，固结不移之状。 实脉，邪气盛则实，精夺则虚。 微脉，为虚，为弱，为衄，为呕，为泄亡汗，为拘急，为中寒微弱，为少气。 濇脉，阴也。 为少血，为亡汗，为气不足，为逆玲，为下痢，为心痛。 若乃不饮，则津液不足，脉道不利，体自濇矣。 细脉，极细而软者。 谓之微，尖於微。 常有但细者，谓之细。 惟其真气虚少，胫酸，髓冷，乏力，折精。 软脉，极软而浮细濡者。 如衣帛在水中，轻手相得，以其血少，不能充实。 弱脉，弱而虚。 为风热，为自汗。 以弱之所主为阴，为虚，为悸故也。 虚脉，为寒，为虚，为怯，为弱，为食不消化，为伤暑。 若夫天真不固，荣卫失守，气血衰耗，於中着之於脉，安得不濡软而虚耶。 散脉。 六府气绝於外，则手足寒，上气五藏。 气绝於内，则下利不禁，甚者不仁。 其脉皆散，散则不聚，病亦危矣。 缓脉。 在下为风，为寒，为弱，为痹，为疼，为不仁，为气不足，为眩晕。

chunks.original_text: 迟脉，为寒，为痛。 故诸阴为寒，寒则浮，水闭胕肿。 结脉，为痰，为饮，为血，为气。 夫人一昼一夜，一万三千五百息之间。 故脉止而复来，可名曰结。 又言，或往或来，聚而却还，曰结。 如四肢气闷，连痛时来，则结脉之病也。 代脉者，一藏绝，他藏代至。 所主形容，赢瘦，口不能言，以明天真惫极也。 动脉，为痛，为惊，为孪，为泄，为恐。 惟其阳欲降，而阴逆之，阴欲升而阳逆之。 两者相博，不得上下，鼓击之势陇然高起，而动脉之形着矣。 故阳有所动，则阳虚矣。 阴有所动，则阴虚矣。 经言，脉者所以决死生，处百病，调虚实，不可不通矣。 如实实虚虚，是谓损不足益有余，此之死者明矣。 虖故脉之字说，言人脉以应月，惟坎之一官。 为水为月以点，为高部上池之水。 以一为中部，霐池之水。 以水为下部，涌众之脉。 荥注大溪，是知三水通灌，可以永寿。 此无竟之液，仍几於道。 先师云：肾之经络属水，是巳上池一点水，生我到如今。 盖养生之方，在乎调气。 故肾藏骨髓之气，肾气寒冽。 寒，阴气也。 如寒邪在肾则病，骨痛，阴痹。 阴痹者，按之不得，腹胀腰痛，大便难，肩背颈项痛时眩。 肾病者，腹颈肿，喘欬，身重，寝汗出，憎风。 肾其病，溪肉之小会，及乎骨髓。 肾病侯，肾象水，王於冬，脉如石而沈。 其侯耳，其声呻，其臭腐，其味咸，其液唾，其养骨，其色黑，其神志足少阴其经也。 与膀胱合，膀胱为府，主表。 肾为藏，主裹。 肾气盛为志，有余则病，腹胀，飧泄，体肿，喘欬，汗出，僧风，面目黑，小便黄，是为肾气之实也。 则宜泻之。 肾气不足则厥，腰背冷，胸中痛，耳呜若聋，是为肾气之虚也。 则宜补之。 肾藏统论曰：肾足少阴经，膀胱足太阳经，相为表裹，其王冬，其象水，其脉沈，其养骨髓，其神精与志，其候耳，其声呻，其臭腐，其味咸，其液唾，其色黑，其气闭藏。 时故早卧晚起，必待日光，去寒就温，无扰乎。 阳为藏养之道，逆冬气则少。 阴不藏，肾气独沈。 其证小腹胀满，小便黄赤，末有余沥，数而痛者，此肾实也。 肾热病者，先腰痛，胻酸苦渴，数饮身热。 凡冬为伤寒，春为温疫，夏为热病。 热争则项痛，而强胻寒且酸足，下热不欲言其逆，则项痛员员澹澹。 然肾热有余，则生於风，而肌与皮皆黑。 以冬壬癸中於邪者，为肾风。 肾风之状，多汗恶风，面庞然浮肿，脊痛不能正，立其色炱，隐曲不利。 诊在肌上色黑，故肾象水。 其气寒冽，寒阴气也。 肾邪入肝，则泪寒。 多则凝泣，及乎筋孪与急，兼骨痛。 肾移寒於肝，则痈肿少气。 肝藏血，然寒入则阳气不散。 故血聚而气涩，邪在肾则病，骨痛阴痹。 阴痹者，按之不得，腹胀腰痛，大便难，肩背颈项痛，时眩。 凡风寒湿三气杂至，为痹。 寒胜则浮，水闭胕肿。 肾之志气不足，则厥逆上冲。 如肾气受邪，水无能润下，焦枯涸，故大便难也。 盖诸寒收引，皆属於肾，诸厥固泄，皆属於下。 诸病水液澄澈清泠，皆属於寒。 凡用寒远寒，如违则寒至。 寒至则坚，否腹满痛，急下利之病生矣。 故寒则伤形，若关格塞，腰背强宜，饮食减少，气力疲乏者，此肾虚也。 凡人内得二不足者，一病癃，一日数十溲，二太阴脉，微细如发，此其身死亦明矣。

The *slow pulse* indicates cold and pain. All yin conditions pertain to cold; when cold prevails, the pulse floats, water stagnates, and edema swells.

The *bound pulse* indicates phlegm, rheum, blood, and *qi*. Within the span of one day and night—13,500 breaths—a pulse that halts and then resumes may be called *bound*. It is also described as moving to and fro, gathering and then retreating, hence *bound*. When the four limbs grow sluggish and pain strikes intermittently, this is the affliction of the *bound pulse*.

The *intermittent pulse* arises when one organ fails and another takes its place. Its manifestations include emaciation, an inability to speak—clear signs of exhausted innate essence.

The *stirring pulse* indicates pain, fright, spasms, diarrhea, and terror. When yang seeks to descend but yin resists, or yin seeks to ascend but yang resists, the two forces contend, unable to move up or down. The pulse surges and strikes, rising abruptly—thus the form of the *stirring pulse* appears. Where yang stirs, yang is deficient; where yin stirs, yin is deficient.

The classics state: *The pulse determines life and death, governs all diseases, and regulates deficiency and excess—one cannot be ignorant of it.* To treat excess as excess and deficiency as deficiency is to harm the insufficient and augment the abundant—such a course leads clearly to death.

Now, the etymology of *pulse*: the human pulse corresponds to the moon, governed by the single trigram *Kan*. As water and moon, it is marked by a dot—representing the high waters of the upper pool. The middle is the central pool, its waters deep and still. The lower is the surging pulse of the multitude. The ancients taught: *The kidney’s meridians belong to water—this single drop from the upper pool has sustained me to this day.* The art of nurturing life lies in regulating *qi*. When kidney evil enters the liver, tears turn cold; in excess, they congeal into weeping, accompanied by sinew spasms and tension, as well as bone pain. chunks.original_text: 大精不足者，补之以味。 形不足者，温之以气。 气味合而服之，可以补精益气。 肾虚者，用苦补之。 实者，以咸泻之。 故□气之方，以吹治之，康宁为期，此□之大略也。 腊残更化，寒星终建季冬之月，丑之临卦，律中大吕。 天道西行，其象在上为磨竭宫，在下为吴，其气在人之脾。 脾为藏，胃为府，象土，王於季，绝於春，死於甲乙，其音宫，其色黄，其性兼静，及喜於和，其养肉，其候唇，其味甘，其臭香，其液涎，其声歌。 脾藏意生思，思伤脾。 脾者，仓廪之官，及为之本营之居也。 脾气兼并，故五味出焉。 其华与荣，在唇之四白，其充在肌肉。 盖人肉应地，但人久坐则伤，肉劳於脾也。 脾劳者，舌本苦直，不得咽唾。 又曰大饱伤脾，脾伤善噫欲卧，面黄有言，饮食劳倦则伤脾，而脾开窍於口，脾和则知五谷矣。 脾为阴中之至阴，脾土位西南方，王四季之月，然冬不按蹻，如辰未戌月。 凡养生之士，尤宜行诸脾。 欲甘，甘先走入脾及肉。 肉病无多食甘，多食甘则骨痛而发落。 脾欲缓急，食甘以缓之。 脾苦湿，急食苦以燥之。 脾禁温衣饱食湿地濡衣，脾恶湿而畏风，风木令也。 精气并於脾，则畏脾热者，色黄而肉蠕动，其鼻先赤。 鼻处面中，土王於中，其变动声，为歌欢哕噫，及乎吞声。 足太阴脾之经，井木为隐白，二穴在足大指内侧端，去爪甲如韭叶。 荥火为太都，二穴在足大指本节后陷中。 腧土为太白，二穴在足内侧，核骨下陷中。 脾俞在第十一椎下两傍。 脾之原，出於太白，经金为商丘，二穴在足内踝下微前陷中。 每昼巽时，人气所在，足太阴脾之经。 及乎巳时，人气亦在脾之络。 巳主右手之少阳，其气亦主脾藏之疾。 丑者十二月，主左足之少阴，兼人气在左，及在於肾。 合水为阴陵泉，二穴在膝下内侧辅骨下。 足太阴脾之脉，起于大指之端，循指内侧白肉际，过腕骨后上内踝前廉上踹，内循胫骨后，交出厌阴之前，上膝股内前廉入腹，属脾络。 胃上膈挟咽连舌本，散舌下。 故脾之平脉缓，贼脉弦，故脉既不常则气从之。 脾藏肌肉之气，脾气兼并，如邪在脾，胃则病，肌肉痛。 脾其病舌本，故病在脾，俞在脊中。 脾病者，身重善肌肉，痿足不收，行善瘈脚下痛。 脾病候，脾象土，王於长夏，其脉缓，其候口，其声歌，其臭香，其味甘，其液涎，其养形肉，其色黄，而藏意，足太阴其经也。 与胃合，胃为府，主表。 脾为藏，主裹，脾气盛为形，有余则病，腹胀满，溲不利，身重善饥，足痿不收，行善瘈，脚下痛，是为脾气之实也。 则宜泻之。 脾气不足，则四支不用，后泄食不化，呕逆腹胀肠鸣，是脾气之虚也。 则宜补之。 总录言，脾位中央，王於仲夏，及四季之月，其脉来，大而缓者，脾平脉也。 若沈细状弱者，脾虚，虚则心腹胀满，水谷不化，呕吐泄利，四肢不用，少气恶闻人声，梦饮食不足，皆脾虚侯。 右手关上，阴脉紧实者，脾实也。 实则身体重，不能转侧，心胸热闷，辱口乾焦，颊痛心急，咽喉不利，舌本强生疮，语声沈重，卧梦歌乐，四肢怠堕，此脾实候。 脾热病者，先头重，颊痛，烦心，颜青，欲呕身热。 热多则筋弛，骨消肉烁，□破热争，则腰痛，不可用俛仰，腹满泄，两颔痛，逆则甲乙死。

Its note is *gong*, its color yellow, its nature both tranquil and harmonious. It nourishes the flesh, manifests in the lips, savors sweetness, emits fragrance, produces saliva, and expresses itself in song.

The spleen stores intention and generates thought; excessive thought harms the spleen. The spleen is the official of the granary and the root of the body’s encampment. When spleen qi converges, the five flavors emerge. Its bloom and glory appear in the four whites of the lips, and its fullness resides in the muscles. As human flesh corresponds to earth, prolonged sitting injures it, for the flesh labors on behalf of the spleen. When the spleen labors, the root of the tongue becomes stiff and bitter, making it difficult to swallow saliva.

It is also said that excessive fullness injures the spleen. When the spleen is injured, one tends to belch, desires to lie down, appears yellow in the face, and speaks with effort. Fatigue from food and exertion harms the spleen, which opens at the mouth; when the spleen is harmonious, one discerns the five grains. The spleen is the utmost yin within yin, its earthly position in the southwest, flourishing in the fourth month of each season—yet in winter, one should not lift the heels, as in the months of *chen*, *wei*, and *xu*.

Those who cultivate life must attend particularly to the spleen. Craving sweetness, sweetness first enters the spleen and flesh. The spleen suffers from dampness; urgently consume bitter to dry it. The spleen forbids warm clothing, overfullness, damp ground, and wet garments. When spleen qi converges, if evil resides in the spleen, the stomach falls ill, and the muscles ache. The spleen’s disease affects the root of the tongue; thus, its transport point lies in the spine’s center.

Spleen disease manifests as heaviness in the body, flaccid muscles, weak feet that cannot be lifted, and a tendency to cramp, with pain under the soles. The spleen’s correspondences: it symbolizes earth, flourishes in late summer, its pulse is moderate, its orifice the mouth, its sound song, its odor fragrance, its flavor sweetness, its fluid saliva, its nourishment the flesh, its color yellow, and it stores intention. The Foot Greater Yin is its channel, paired with the stomach, which is the *fu*-organ governing the exterior. The spleen is the *zang*-organ governing containment.

When spleen qi is exuberant, it shapes the form; in excess, it causes illness: abdominal distension and fullness, inhibited urination, heaviness in the body, constant hunger, weak feet that cannot be lifted, a tendency to cramp, and pain under the soles—this is spleen qi excess, and purging is appropriate. When spleen qi is insufficient, the four limbs fail to function, with undigested food in diarrhea, vomiting, counterflow, abdominal distension, and borborygmi—this is spleen qi deficiency, and tonifying is appropriate.

In summary, the spleen resides in the center, flourishing in mid-summer and the fourth month of each season. Its pulse arrives large and moderate—this is the spleen’s balanced pulse. Deficiency causes abdominal fullness, undigested food, vomiting, diarrhea, inability to use the four limbs, shortness of breath, aversion to human voices, and dreams of insufficient food—all signs of spleen deficiency.

When the yin pulse at the right *guan* position is tight and replete, the spleen is in excess. chunks.original_text: 真元门生李景元集解 卢氏究五藏言，但人喉咙中排三窍，一曰食，二曰气，三曰水，递互相排推。 食与水同一窍，并合归於胃中。 上口一窍归於肺，通行太阴之脉，下循腹裹，抵脊膂中，转行脐下，与任脉、冲脉、督脉三经，会於丹田者，人之生气之海也。 脐下三寸，方圆四寸，附着脊膂两肾之间，一名大海，溺水中有神龟，呼吸元气，流行上达夹脐，络胃贯肝膈，入肺中，以升降之气，通行呼吸往来，造化之理，唯是肺之上一窍也。 其水食之窍，同并入胃，全假丹田之气，施化以变糟粕。 水谷分清浊，行乎小肠大肠，使阴阳之气，造化传注。 阳气多，则使水谷化成。 阴气多，则糟粕不化。 为寒为痛，是为阳阻阴而不降，阴无阳而不升，此阴阳升降之理也。 喉咙下见肺两叶，为华盖，覆於诸藏也。 肺下见心外有黄脂包裹，其色稍赤黄。 人心之像，尖长圆扁，黑赤青黄，毛孔各异而弗仝焉。 心下有罗膈，罗膈下有胃，积曲可容数升之物，外有黄脂如旗焰。 左畔有肝两叶，其短叶上有胆。 在胃左畔有脾，与胃同其膜，其状如马肝赤紫。 下有小肠，盘十五曲，极莹浄，化物通行。 右畔有大肠，亦盘十六曲，内有糟粕，外有黄脂，粘为一块。 下有膀胱所居胞也，亦莹净，外无所入之穴，全假施行，则津液入於胞中为溺也。 《内经》 曰：膀胱为州都之官，津液藏焉，气化则能出矣。 右畔有大肠所出糟粕之道路。 乃五藏之真己，惟肾为根。 凡人肾虚，水不足也。 多以燥药，弗知其恶，未若益之，以味补之。 於毋，肺为阴毋昭矣。 穷理藏府，己得其详，则背输看其五藏之景，有出入死生之道，乃圣人般运黄河逆流之法。 唯行此诀，乃得长生之理。 观其第十四椎下两傍，各一寸五分，有肾两枚，亦自各有黄脂包裹为一块，各有带二条，乃为肾之大经也。 过屏翳穴后，趋脊骨之下，有一大骨在脊骨之端，如半手许，其间有两穴，是肾之经。 经过上行，夹脊至泥丸脑户中，脑者是髓之海也。 若人得其术般运，不妄漏泄，而泝流至於泥丸，为大丹，可以长生久视。 斯道也者，昔黄帝得之，成而登天。 而后安期三千，彭祖八百，具载《神仙传》 中。 故飞升住世，此两者有矣。 夫朗然子外丹，达恍惚杳冥之旨，内气明沂，流胎息之源，功勤未及於旬年，人惊不老，寿算已踰於五纪，自觉如新。 身中自有升天路，背上谁无出世纹。 夹脊关至顶门，修行径路此为根。 华池玉液频须咽，紫府元君遣上奔。 常使气冲关节透，自然精满谷神存。 外药已知消息火，内丹常运泝流律。 假饶千载重相见，也似如今貌转新。 莫言大道人难会，自是顽夫不学仙。 刘子述太上气诀，□疾苦神或有忽而哂之者，盖未达玄功，用必差互，乃无应验而见非矣。 迩者，民女为鬼所着，少师断之，鬼转返追，少师犇焉。 过真君堂，老师即见，速擒鬼魂。 断遣竟，因论其详。 缘当日甲子，少师差乙丑神将吏兵，而见逐，老师使甲子当日神将吏兵，遂擒之。 故正一法式，毫发差殊尚尔，况乎□气之诀，由之弗当，必无应验，则有哂忽之人哉。 及乎群经浩渺，拟穷病源者，则速讨难见。 约文枢要，将明证候者，则开缄易知。 夫然所贵修身之士，疾疹康宁，而进妙真之道，不其伟欤。

Master Li Jingyuan of the True Origin Gate offers this commentary:

The physician Lu exhaustively examined the five viscera, noting that within the human throat lie three passages: one for food, one for qi, and one for water, each sequentially propelling the others. The passages for food and water share a single orifice, converging together into the stomach. The upper orifice leads to the lungs, connecting to the Greater Yin meridian, descending through the abdomen, reaching the spine’s center, then circling beneath the navel to join the Conception, Thoroughfare, and Governing Vessels at the Cinnabar Field—the sea of generative qi. Three inches below the navel, spanning four inches in width, it adheres between the spine and the two kidneys. Known also as the Great Sea, within its waters dwells a spirit-turtle that draws in primordial qi, circulating it upward past the navel, weaving through the stomach, penetrating the liver and diaphragm, and entering the lungs. Here, the ascending and descending qi facilitate the ebb and flow of breath, for this is the sole passage above the lungs. The passages for water and food both enter the stomach, entirely dependent on the qi of the Cinnabar Field to transform and transmute their essence. Water and grain separate into the pure and turbid, traversing the small and large intestines, where the interplay of yin and yang qi governs their transformation and transmission. When yang qi prevails, water and grain are refined; when yin qi dominates, the dregs remain unrefined, giving rise to cold and pain. Below the throat, the two lobes of the lungs appear, serving as the Florid Canopy that shelters all the viscera. Beneath the lungs lies the heart, enveloped in a yellow fatty membrane of a reddish-yellow hue. The heart’s form is pointed, elongated, round, and flat, its color a blend of black, red, green, and yellow, with pores distinct and unalike. Below the heart lies the diaphragm, and beneath that, the stomach, coiled to hold several *sheng* of matter, encased in a yellow fatty membrane resembling a banner’s flame. Beside the stomach on the left rests the spleen, sharing its membrane, resembling horse liver in its reddish-purple hue. Below lies the small intestine, coiled in fifteen loops, gleaming and pure, transmuting and conveying matter. To the right lies the large intestine, coiled in sixteen loops, containing dregs and enveloped in yellow fat, clumped together. Having thoroughly examined the principles of the viscera and bowels, one may observe the reflections of the five viscera upon the back’s transport points, discerning the pathways of life and death. Observe the fourteenth vertebra below, on either side at a distance of one *cun* and five *fen*, where the two kidneys reside. Though the effort may not span a full decade, others marvel at one’s agelessness, for the span of life already exceeds five cycles. One feels renewed, for within the body lies the path to heaven, and upon the back, who lacks the mark of transcendence? From the *Jiaji* to the crown, this is the direct route of cultivation. Frequently swallow the Jade Fluid of the Flowery Pond, and the Primordial Lord of the Purple Palace will send it upward. Constantly ensure qi penetrates the joints, and naturally, essence will fill and the Valley Spirit will abide.

Once the external medicine’s fire is understood, the internal elixir’s reverse flow is perpetually activated. Even if a thousand years pass before we meet again, you will appear as youthful as today. Do not say the Great Dao is difficult to comprehend—it is only that the stubborn refuse to learn immortality.

Master Liu expounded the Supreme Qi Formula. Some, afflicted by illness or suffering, may scoff at it in neglect, failing to grasp its profound workings. Misapplication yields no results, and thus they dismiss it. Recently, a woman possessed by a ghost was exorcised by a Junior Master, but the ghost turned and pursued him. Fleeing past the True Lord’s hall, the Teacher immediately perceived the situation and swiftly captured the ghost’s spirit. After the exorcism, they discussed the details. On that day, a *jiazi* day, the Junior Master had dispatched the *yichou* spirit generals and soldiers, who were thus repelled. The Teacher, however, employed the *jiazi* day’s own spirit generals and soldiers, thereby capturing the ghost. Thus, in the Orthodox Unity method, even a hair’s breadth of deviation leads to such outcomes—how much more so for the qi formula, where misapplication guarantees no results, inviting scorn and neglect.

Yet by distilling the essentials, clarifying symptoms becomes effortless upon opening the text. Is this not the very virtue of those who cultivate the body—to attain health and well-being, and to advance in the wondrous Dao of the True? How magnificent indeed!

chunks.original_text: 真元门人为明童言：将欲洽天而惩恶，莫越传经而劝善。 时在戊辰孟春七日，恭默思师，闻诸孔父谓之圣人，犹问礼於老聃，访乐於苌弘，况乎愚何人哉，敢不奉师。 尤蒙师长仁慈，授《开化》之经，统而论之，所为明皇天尊，主君臣父子之道。 故修之天下，言圣君之道，贵乎仁爱於天下； 修之於国，言忠臣之道，贵乎敬顺於长上； 修之於卿，言辅佐之道，贵乎恭敬惠义； 修之於家言孝悌之道贵乎礼乐和睦修之於身，言虚静之道，贵乎保护冲和。 如斯罔阙，方当洽于妙真之门。 次授《演范》之经，所谓明皇教主，开化群生。 始论道德五常之式，中论摄养冲和之气，终论明照住世之科。 从兹弗怠，将契妙真之宫。 又其次授《真元》之经，所为真元教主，贵乎务改其不善，今为其大慈，内则冲虚而无为，外则神化而有益。 如是之用，方号真元。 再授《大洞》之经，所为清微天官妙无上帝，启龙章大洞之典，垂凤纪真元之科。 故有雌一之玄，雄一之秘。 天地得之以清宁，日月得之以明照，阴阳得之以升条，物我得之以长久。 若人习学大洞，妙有真无，道德兼济，仍合妙真。 继授《大洞图书》及自然篇，言人禀天地，道法自然，但有形无情，悉由一尔。 故圣人无为也，不先物为也。 因其自然而推之，及乎法象图书，明日月尚有数，而大小岂无定。 凡生成之类，罔不有之。 故万物负阴而抱阳，冲气以为和。 盖得和者则生，失和者何足以言哉。 竟授《妙真》之经，初明清微天主，传空洞妙真帝一无为之道； 中演禹余天生，授束华妙有帝真救生之德； 终说大赤天主，敷太虚真无玄一度人之教。 及乎调十二经络，所贵安和欣乐，然后集妙有之道，真无之宗。 故得元气为生化之基，阳神乃登仙之奥，道德兼济，即名妙真。 以上经范，咸化众生，遄革非为，顿徂善道。 若出家修行人，自有高上明师度之。 或在家奉真者，岂无均天教典诱诸。 释氏 明月分形处处新，白衣宁坠解空人。 谁言在俗妨修道，金粟曾为长者身。 得之於心，伊兰作旃檀之树。 失之於旨，甘露乃蒺草藜之园。 洞滨 滚滚洪波贪爱欲，谁人肯上渡仙船。 道隐无名身在道，两端□理号真元。 故得其要者，一言而终。 不知其要，流散无穷。 呜呼。 无念奉道者众，得遇者鲜。 於戏，鲜者多迷，且一人迷犹可证，众人迷不可证。 奈何。 且教主贵为天子，尚深悼之。 况乎愚昧，乌能证哉。 然聪明上士，讵一而不忤邪，但占览察妙真之道者，则昭然洞达，列仙之猷。 若能遇焉，尤宜勉旃。 大梁羁旅俾污丐者，曩时在戊辰年贞元日，受师诸经，全帙切怪，缮写□谬，篆文乖讹。 缅望收经，高士塾訾，校证勖厉，宜诸如是之为，诲人不倦，无乃未可乎。 昔乎龙集甲子上元日，在真元观焚修间，俄有玄天上帝，飞降法言，称妙真宝科，自於帝尧，乃上方道德天尊之应躬也。 可传善人，愚老愈也。 斋沐谨志，洎明其源，意愿训注。

The disciples of the True Origin School addressed the enlightened youths: To govern the heavens and punish evil, nothing surpasses transmitting the scriptures and exhorting goodness.

On the seventh day of the first lunar month in the *wuchen* year, reverently reflecting upon the Teacher, I recall how Confucius—the very paragon of the sages—still inquired of Laozi about rites and sought counsel from Chang Hong on music. How then could I, a fool, dare not honor my master? Especially when the master, in boundless benevolence, bestowed the *Scripture of Enlightenment*, which, in its essence, expounds the August Heavenly Worthy as the sovereign of the Way of ruler and minister, father and son.

Thus, when cultivated throughout the world, it speaks of the sagely ruler’s Way, prizing benevolence and love for all under heaven. When cultivated within a state, it speaks of the loyal minister’s Way, prizing reverence and obedience to superiors. When cultivated among ministers, it speaks of the Way of assisting governance, prizing respect, kindness, and righteousness. When cultivated within the family, it speaks of the filial and fraternal Way, prizing ritual, music, and harmony. When cultivated in the self, it speaks of the Way of emptiness and quiescence, prizing the preservation of harmonious qi. Only when none of these are lacking may one be deemed fit for the gate of the Wondrous True.

Next was bestowed the *Scripture of Extended Models*, which reveals the August Teaching Lord who enlightens all beings. It begins with the standards of virtue and the Five Constants, proceeds to the nurturing of harmonious qi, and concludes with the precepts for luminous illumination and abiding in the world. Through unwavering diligence, one may attain union with the palace of the Wondrous True.

Following this was the *Scripture of the True Origin*, which expounds the Lord of the True Origin, emphasizing the transformation of unwholesome traits. Through great compassion, one cultivates inner emptiness and non-action while outwardly manifesting numinous transformation for the benefit of all. Such is the practice rightly called the True Origin.

Then was granted the *Scripture of the Great Cavern*, which reveals the August Emperor of the Mysterious and Infinitesimal Heavenly Palace, unfolding the dragon-script canon of the Great Cavern and bequeathing the phoenix-records of the True Origin’s precepts. Herein lies the mystery of the Feminine One and the secrecy of the Masculine One. Heaven and Earth attain clarity and tranquility through it; the sun and moon gain their luminous radiance; yin and yang ascend and flourish; and all beings endure in harmony. Should one study the Great Cavern, mastering the wondrous existence and true non-being, and harmonizing virtue and power, one merges with the Wondrous True.

Subsequently were bestowed the *Charts and Writings of the Great Cavern* and the *Natural Chapters*, which declare that humans receive their nature from Heaven and Earth, and the Dao models itself upon spontaneity. All that has form yet lacks sentience arises from this singular source. Thus, the sage does not act before things do, nor does he precede them. Instead, he follows their natural course and extends it. As for the celestial patterns and charts, even the sun and moon adhere to their measures—how could great and small lack their proper bounds? All things that come into being possess them. Therefore, the myriad beings bear yin on their backs and embrace yang in their arms, harmonizing through the qi of the center. Those who attain harmony live; those who lose it—what can be said of them?

Finally was granted the *Scripture of the Wondrous True*, which first clarifies the Lord of the Mysterious and Infinitesimal Heaven, transmitting the non-actional Dao of the Imperial One of the Empty Cavern and Wondrous True. It then expounds the life-generating virtue of the Lord of the Jade-Conserving Heaven, who bestows the Eastern Florescence and the Wondrous Existence. Lastly, it sets forth the teachings of the Lord of the Great Vermilion Heaven, spreading the numinous non-being and the singular transformation of the Primal Human. It further regulates the twelve meridians, prizing peace, harmony, and joy. Only then may one gather the Way of wondrous existence and the lineage of true non-being. Thus, the primordial qi becomes the foundation of life and transformation, and the yang spirit the mystery of transcendence. When virtue and power are harmonized, one is called the Wondrous True.

The above scriptures and models all transform beings, swiftly correcting wrongdoing and hastening them toward the good Way. For those who leave the household to cultivate the Dao, there are exalted and enlightened masters to guide them. For those who remain in the world to revere the True, are there not the celestial teachings to instruct them?

The Buddhist verse:
*Bright moon divides its form, ever renewed in every place,*
*Can the white-robed fall behind those who comprehend emptiness?*
*Who says the laity hinder the cultivation of the Dao?*
*Golden Grain once took the form of the Elder’s body.*

When grasped in the heart, the foul *ilan* becomes the sandalwood tree. When the essence is lost, even nectar turns to a garden of thorns and brambles.

The *Dongbin* verse:
*Rolling waves of desire, who will board the immortal’s ferry?*
*The Dao lies hidden, nameless—yet the body abides in the Dao.*
*Dual principles □ the principle—this is called the True Origin.*

Thus, those who grasp the essentials may conclude with a single word. Those who do not know the essentials scatter endlessly.

Alas! Many revere the Dao without thought, yet few encounter its truth. How lamentable that the few who err may yet be corrected, but when the many err, none can be saved. What is to be done?

Even the Teaching Lord, though noble as the Son of Heaven, deeply mourned this. How much more so for the ignorant—how could they attain realization? Yet the wise and enlightened, though they may stumble, need only glimpse the Wondrous True Dao to perceive it with luminous clarity, following the path of the ranked immortals. Should one encounter it, one must strive with utmost diligence.

A sojourner in the land of Great Liang, once reduced to beggary, on the *zhengyuan* day of the *wuchen* year, received from the master these scriptures in their entirety. Yet I marveled at their completeness, and in transcribing them, errors crept into the seal script. From afar, I yearn for the recovery of these texts. May the noble scholars correct and encourage, for such is the way of tireless instruction—would this not be fitting?

Long ago, on the *shangyuan* day of the *jiazi* year, while engaged in purification rites at the True Origin Abbey, the August Heavenly Emperor of the Dark Mystery suddenly descended, delivering a divine pronouncement: "The precious precepts of the Wondrous True originated with Emperor Yao and are the incarnate response of the Heavenly Worthy of the Dao and Virtue from the Upper Realm. They may be transmitted to the virtuous; this foolish old man has benefited greatly." With reverence, I bathed and recorded this, tracing its source and intent, wishing to elucidate its teachings.

To cultivate one’s own perfection alone, delighting solely in the Three Caverns, how does this compare to sharing its bounty widely across the nine directions, that all may together bathe in the Mysterious Blessing? This is the sincere aspiration of my heart.
